Oral Answers to Questions

Page: 548

London Cabs for Wheelchair-Bound Commuters

1 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Transport in view of the expiry of licences for operators of London cabs by March 2012 (a) how would the Ministry help those who are wheelchair-bound to get better mobility on taxis; (b) whether LTA would work out a suitable arrangement with SMRT to continue operating the London cabs until a suitable long-term solution is found for wheelchair bound commuters; and (c) whether LTA would give special dispensation to transport operators to incentivise them to apply for licences to run London cabs.

The Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank Ms Lee for her question. Let me assure the Member that the Government understands the concerns of wheelchair users in having access to transport services which meet their needs. As announced by the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports on 10 November 2011, LTA will support MCYS to identify feasible solutions through working with the Enabling Masterplan Steering Committee and related stakeholders. Sir, this is an umbrella review of inter-related policies and will take some time. In the meantime, LTA has agreed to work with SMRT to extend the statutory lifespan of all the 15 units of the London Taxis for an additional year up to March 2013.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah (Nee Soon) : Mr Speaker, Sir, supplementary questions for the Minister of State. What if by March 2013 there is no solution? What alternatives will be given? The next question is: before SMRT announced that it would terminate the services of the London taxis, were there any discussions with LTA? Is the SMRT's decision based on commercial reasons, that is, based on the bottom line and in answer to the shareholders, or were there any other reasons?

Mrs Josephine Teo : Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the question of what other alternatives would be made available, it is a little too early to say right now. The Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports had indicated that the needs assessment alone, that is to do a comprehensive job, would take two to three months. Thereafter, it would be in both MCYS' and LTA's interests to try and meet the needs as best as they possibly can. On the other question of what was behind the SMRT's decision-making process, SMRT itself had come out to explain that the take-up rate for the London taxis was not as high as they had anticipated. Notwithstanding the fact that there were a number of the cab drivers who were willing to continue, in fact, there are quite a number of the London taxis that are not leased out by SMRT. Among the 15 units of London taxis which are currently registered, there is actually a number of units that are not hired. In other words, the take-up rate is not as high.

Page: 549

Controls on Licensed Moneylenders

2 Mr Alex Yam asked the Minister for Law (a) if he would provide the latest update on the number of licensed moneylenders who have contravened the Moneylenders Act for misleading advertising and marketing materials; (b) what plans would be put in place to ensure that advertising and marketing materials of moneylenders in the print media adhere to the Act; and (c) whether his Ministry would consider amending the Act to further strengthen controls on moneylending.

3 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Law (a) whether there is a quota imposed on the number of licences issued to moneylenders; and (b) what is the framework governing the applications and practices of licensed moneylenders.

The Minister for Law (Mr K Shanmugam) : Sir, with your leave, I will take Question Nos 2 and 3 together, please.

Mr Speaker : Yes.

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, Ms Tin asks if there is a quota on the number of moneylending licences, and what is the framework governing the applications and practices of licensed moneylenders.

The Registry has not imposed a quota on moneylending licences. What the Registry has done is impose rigorous requirements on licence applicants and licensees. For example, as part of the application process, the Registry conducts robust checks on the licence applicant and all other persons involved in his business to ensure that they are fit and proper persons. The Registry also requires all moneylending business outlets to be managed by a qualified manager.

On 1 November 2011, a set of new rules was implemented to tighten the governance of licensed moneylenders. These require, amongst others, moneylenders to seek the Registry's approval for the engagement and employment of any person to assist in their business. The new rules also further safeguard the interests of borrowers by, for example, disallowing moneylenders from disclosing any information about their borrowers to third parties without obtaining the prior written consent of the borrower, and prohibiting moneylenders from making any upfront deduction of interest payments from the principal loan.

Page: 550

Sir, let me now address the questions concerning advertising by moneylenders raised by Mr Yam. We have allowed advertising so as to allow borrowers to more easily compare the terms between different moneylenders and choose the best one for their needs. Under the Moneylenders Act, all such advertisements must be accurate and not be false or misleading.

We are concerned that excessive advertising could encourage excessive and unnecessary borrowing. Thus, the Registry has implemented new rules, also on 1 November 2011, to regulate more strictly the advertising and marketing activities of moneylenders. Under these rules, moneylenders are allowed to advertise only through specific channels – business directories, on their business website, and at their business premises. They are no longer allowed to advertise through other channels, in particular newspapers and through SMSes.

Since the implementation of the new rules, the Registry has been monitoring advertisements in various channels, including the newspapers and the Internet, as well as investigating complaints. As of 14 November 2011, 32 licensed moneylenders were found to have committed breaches of the new advertising rules. All the 32 moneylenders had been warned and have since complied with the Registry's instructions to rectify the breaches. If they repeat the breaches, the Registry will take stern enforcement action, which may result in the revocation of their licence, and for even more serious breaches, prosecution in court. Where advertisements were found to be by unlicensed moneylenders, they have been referred to the Police for investigation.

As mentioned in this House before, we will keep a close watch on the moneylending industry. We are reviewing other aspects of the industry and will take further steps to tighten regulation and protect borrowers, as may be necessary.

Mr Alex Yam (Chua Chu Kang) : One supplementary question, Sir. I would first like to thank the Minister for the update on the change to the guidelines since 1 November 2011 and the actions taken by the Registry since then. With the outreach of the moneylenders now extending beyond the traditional older generation of borrowers towards a far larger and younger pool of borrowers, would the Registry under the Ministry of Law also consider including guidelines or compulsory education for borrowers on their commitments in the future?

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, the Ministry of Law, in another context, in the context of bankruptcy, has started a series of processes to educate Singaporeans on better management of their own finances. We have not really thought in terms of outreach for young people on how they should handle their finances. We will certainly consider that, but it is likely to be an extensive exercise and we need to be careful about going down that road.

Page: 550

Increased HDB Rental Rates

4 Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many lessees of HDB rental flats had been affected by rental hikes in the last two years; (b) what was the basis of the rental adjustment and the percentage of increase; and (c) whether HDB would consider reversing this increase for those households living in poverty in view of the increasing cost of living.

Page: 551

The Minister for National Development (Mr Khaw Boon Wan) : Sir, HDB rentals are adjusted at the time of tenancy renewal, if the income of the tenants has changed. This is useful to those who suffer an income reduction. This policy ensures that rental subsidy goes more to those who earn less. On the other hand, this encourages tenants whose financial circumstances have improved to eventually move on to home ownership, giving up their rental flats for needier families.

In the last two years, 1,100 tenants had their rents reduced, while 5,100 had rents adjusted upwards. The percentage increase in rental rate will depend on the extent of the increase in household income. The principle of charging higher rent for higher income is sound. However, where there are individual cases of financial hardship as a result of the rental adjustment, we can review them and re-adjust if necessary.

Dr Lily Neo (Tanjong Pagar) : Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister, for those HDB rental lessees who have attained a certain higher income, instead of raising their HDB rental further, would the Minister consider selling two-room HDB flats to these lower-income tenants who can then use CPF monies to pay for their home, rather than paying more in cash for increasing rentals that eat into their daily needs? Does the Minister not agree that such a measure is consistent with the established long-term tenor of the Government's policy on home-ownership for Singaporeans?

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Indeed, our intent is to encourage ownership rather than rental. We would prefer to be seller rather than landlord. Those who are capable, we should try to encourage them in that direction. So, in principle, yes, I agree with the Member. The specifics, we will have to look into them, because sometimes there may be circumstances which forbid them from getting a further HDB loan, without which they may not be able to conclude the purchase. We will have to take a look at the individual cases. But like the Member, I will always be sympathetic.

Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Nee Soon) : Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether there were many instances whereby the lessees had difficulties paying the new rentals, and what the HDB had done or is doing to assist them or in engaging them to pay the revised rental rates.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Sir, the answer is, yes, there are cases where tenants have had difficulties, and it will show up in the form of arrears. We try to look into each arrear with care, and those repeated arrear or chronic arrear cases, HDB will assign case managers to try to find a way out for the families.

Dr Lily Neo : Sir, the Minister said earlier that HDB had in the last two years increased HDB rentals to about 5,100 lessees. May I ask the Minister whether in our present climate of rising cost of living and stagnant wages for the lowest income group, are we not putting too much pressure on them and putting them in struggle of their daily living?

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not one who likes to put pressure. I do not like pressure myself and, like the Member, I am always sympathetic. But as I explained in the reply, where there have been salary adjustments, then tenants go up to a different rental tier. I think it is fair that if you are earning more, then your subsidy will be less than those who are earning less. But, as I said, there will always be some family situations where despite the increase in salary, they may not be able to cope. We will always be sympathetic.

Page: 552

Income Eligibility Criteria for Rental Housing

5 Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Minister for National Development if he would consider reviewing the income eligibility criteria for rental housing in view of the increased median income and higher costs of living in Singapore.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Sir, the current income ceiling for HDB rental units is set at $1,500. This adequately covers the lowest 20% income households. In practice, HDB exercises flexibility so that those earning above $1,500 can still get public rental flats, if they are unable to purchase a flat, have no family support or other housing options. Our focus, however, should be on helping as many as possible to become home owners. And this is a point that Dr Lily Neo mentioned just now too. This is made possible even for low-income Singaporeans because of the additional help the Government gives to them.

If I may illustrate, the average price of a two-room flat in a recent BTO launch in my Sembawang constituency was about $107,000. A family earning $1,500 a month will be eligible for a Government Housing Grant of $60,000. His monthly mortgage instalment will be about $190. This can be paid entirely through their CPF contributions without any cash outlay. Indeed, the median income of those who apply for two-room flats in recent BTO launches was $1,400. This is below the income ceiling for public rental housing.

Dr Lam Pin Min (Sengkang West) : Sir, I thank the Minister for the answer. According to the Department of Statistics' 2010 report on key household income trends in 2010, the median income had increased from about $3,638 in 2000 to about $5,000 in 2010, that is, over the past 10 years. I would like to ask the Minister when was the income ceiling of $1,500 set for rental housing? Was it many, many years ago? Considering the fact that the median household income has increased, plus inflation, would it not be timely to review the income criterion at this point in time?

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : While the median income has moved, the bottom 20 percentile has not.

Mr Pritam Singh (Aljunied) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Minister for those clarifications. At the beginning, if I heard him correctly, the Minister suggested that the rental amount – the limit of $1,500 – there was a range that the HDB would consider above on a case-by-case basis. Can I just enquire from the Minister what is the nature of that range above $1,500 where the HDB will exercise some flexibility, if there is a range?

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : As I said, it is very hard to prescribe a formula because the circumstances of families do differ. You may have huge or small families. The circumstances can vary a lot. Even if you have small families, you may have other circumstances, like medical or chronic illness which exert different expenses on the family. These are the sorts of details that we need when we look at individual cases. And the fact is that it is not uncommon to have households earning more than $1,500 and living in our rental flats.

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song (Non-Constituency Member) : Mr Speaker, Sir, just a point of clarification for the Minister. He has said that there is no formula for the discretion to allow those earning a bit more than $1,500 to still rent HDB flats. But would the Minister consider a formula whereby even those who are earning above that amount can get a rental flat but have to pay a higher tier rental? Because the reality seems to be that there are many people who are not able to afford the BTO flats because of different circumstances: they may not be first-time buyers, they may have sold their previous flat. And so the gap between the public rentals and the open-market rentals is really great right now. Would the Minister consider something where there is a tier in between such that someone can pay a certain amount of rent that is not, say, $800 a month, but maybe about $200 or $300?

Page: 553

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Sorry, I missed the last sentence. What is that $800 and $200 again?

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song : I was just giving some figures as to whether or not there can be an interim tier between what people pay right now for public rental versus what they pay for the open-market rental, to make it more affordable for them.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : The Member quoted some examples where families may be earning a higher income than $1,500, but might not be able to buy a BTO flat despite the affordability of BTO flats, because they have bought a couple of flats before. And precisely it was because of those circumstances that we made exceptions to allow them to rent. But I think the strategic intent must be that, wherever feasible, we should try to get them onto the road back to home-ownership rather than permanent rental. My objective will always be for permanent ownership rather than permanent tenancy because, tenancy, as Dr Lily Neo put it just now, is consumption rather than some sort of investment in property. Whether we can have higher rental for those earning above $1,500, that is, paying rental above what is currently prescribed, is something we can take a look at, as we make exceptions. I belong to that school of thought too. Currently, the rental is capped at, I think, less than $10 a day. But for some families who exceed the income ceiling of $1,500 and could not go on to home-ownership yet, there may be a higher rental tier to help them in between. This is something we are looking at.

Page: 553

Use of Post Secondary Education Account (PSEA) Funds for Degree Courses

6 Mr Zainal Sapari asked the Minister for Education if the Ministry could allow National Servicemen to use the NS Incentive Award that is credited into their Post Secondary Education Account (PSEA) to finance their degree courses at private institutions in Singapore other than at Singapore Management University and SIM University as long as their courses are permitted by the Council for Private Education.

The Minister of State for Education (Mr Lawrence Wong) (for the Minister for Education) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank Mr Zainal for his question and suggestion. Currently, monies from the Post Secondary Education Account (PSEA) can be used to pay the fees of full-time and part-time Government-subsidised courses at publicly-funded institutions, where there is greater assurance of the quality and education outcomes. These include degree programmes at our four Autonomous Universities (NUS, NTU, SMU and the new SUTD), the Singapore Institute of Technology and UniSIM, as well as diploma programmes at our five polytechnics; NITEC and Higher NITEC programmes at ITE; and MOE-subsidised programmes at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts and the LASALLE School of the Arts.

Page: 554

Nevertheless, we note that there has been public feedback to extend some form of financing support, including the use of PSEA funds, to students who choose to pursue degrees in private education institutions. As Members are aware, I currently chair a Committee on University Expansion Pathways, and the Committee is looking not just at increasing the number of places for university students but also the affordability and financing of university education. So, this suggestion is something that the Committee would look at in the course of our deliberations.

Page: 554

Deaths at Reservoirs

(Impact and preventive measures)

7 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources in view of the six reported cases of bodies taken out of reservoirs, notably four in the last four months (a) what other measures to prevent occurrences of such incidents will the PUB adopt other than the usual beefing up of security and putting up of warning signs around the reservoirs; and (b) whether the Ministry will set up a committee to look into the impact on the water quality and the psychological effects of these incidents.

The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) : Mr Speaker, Sir, let me begin by expressing our condolences to the families of all those who have passed away in the vicinity of our reservoirs. There are fundamentally two key issues that we need to address. First, why do we open our reservoirs to the public and, secondly, the safety of our water supply.

Let me deal with the first point. Since 2004, PUB has opened up most of our reservoirs for recreational activities which include kayaking, canoeing, dragon-boating and spot fishing. This has enabled many people to enjoy access to our water bodies and also encourage stronger community ownership of our reservoirs. The purpose of this is to ensure people come closer to water, and feel a stake in maintaining the cleanliness of our reservoirs. Furthermore, this is a beautiful, natural resource and I think it should be made available to the citizens of our country.

The opening of the reservoirs was done with careful consideration for public safety. If any Member has visited, you would find that there are safety measures such as warning signs, life buoys, safety barriers and clear demarcation of the areas within the reservoirs which are available for public use. All the activities on the water have to be conducted by organised and formal groups. All such operators are required to comply with very stringent safety procedures which are imposed by PUB. These procedures would include safety briefings to all participants and ensuring that every participant in the water has a personal floatation device. PUB conducts regular audits on all these operators to ensure strict compliance with these required safety procedures. In addition, PUB officers also conduct regular patrols to ensure that reservoir facilities are used in a safe manner. PUB has also worked with Police to step up their patrols in reservoirs and particularly in Bedok Reservoir. We have also adopted a suggestion from the public, and we are putting up more signs at the Bedok reservoir grounds which will provide information on support helpline for those who are depressed.

In recent months, a number of bodies have been found in our reservoirs. Of the cases so far, only one has gone through a formal Coroner's Inquiry and in that particular case, the Coroner recorded an open verdict which means there was not sufficient evidence to determine the specific cause of death. For the other cases, formal investigations are still ongoing. The Coroner's Inquiry has not been held yet and, therefore, we should not speculate on the specific circumstances of each particular case at this point in time. Having said that, PUB's internal investigations into the circumstances into all these cases so far have not attributed any of these deaths to water activities within the reservoir itself.

Page: 555

Even with the measures that have been put in place, we still require people to exercise personal care and take responsibility for their own safety in our reservoirs. We therefore seek the cooperation of all members of the public to exercise their rights to use the reservoirs facilities and waters carefully. And also to help us by alerting the PUB or the Police if they notice anyone behaving suspiciously or in an unsafe manner in the vicinity of our reservoirs.

Mrs Chiam has asked about the impact of these incidents on our water quality, and this indeed is a serious issue, and is the second point that I want to elaborate on. Fortunately for us, all these incidents have occurred in reservoirs containing raw water, that is, untreated water. Before water reaches the taps and our glasses, it has to undergo several steps of filtration and chemical disinfection in order to ensure that it is safe to drink. PUB continually monitors water quality in all our reservoirs and in our treatment plants to ensure that water is safe for consumption. Reservoir water is chemically treated, filtered, and disinfected in our waterworks to a high standard, well within World Health Organization's Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality. This treatment process eliminates the bacteria which may be found from decaying organic material found naturally in the reservoirs' ecosystems. The treated water is tested daily for many chemical and biological parameters. PUB also engages an External Audit Panel, comprising local and international experts, to independently assess the toxicology, water quality and chemistry of our water. We would like therefore to assure the public that the recent incidents, although tragic, have not compromised the safety of drinking water for the public.

Mrs Lina Chiam (Non-Constituency Member) : Sir, I thank the Minister for answering the question. May I ask: did the Government intensify its water purification after five bodies were discovered at Bedok Reservoir? This is a serious matter, even if one ant drops into my water, I would not want to drink it. Did the Government intensify the purification of the water? Or was it just the normal process? Secondly, would the Government form a task force comprising experts and people who have overcome suicides to brainstorm for ideas and find quick solutions to stop this disturbing issue from happening again?

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan : Sir, I thank the Member for those two questions. First, on the question of whether we intensified any activity: we certainly intensified all our measures to prevent these sorts of untoward accidents. So, we reviewed all the safety parameters, we increased patrolling, we increased lightings, we put up more signs. Specifically, on water safety, there was no need to change the operating procedure to filter, treat and check the water. We stepped up our monitoring and we ensured that everybody in the water treatment plants that are dealing with raw water from Bedok Reservoir, have complied strictly with all our procedures. But the standard operating procedure to ensure that the water is clean did not need to be changed.

On the task force for suicide: I am glad the Member brought that up because in fact, this illustrates that this is a problem that goes beyond our reservoirs. And since I came from MCYS in the past, I can say that we know there have been other preferred modes of suicide which have been influenced by media coverage and the way it is portrayed to the public. But the Member is quite right; the root of the issue is people who are depressed and who are having difficulty coping with life. We need a multi-pronged approach for this. Frequency of MRT Trains During Peak Hours

8 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Transport (a) whether there are any constraints that prevent MRT trains from running at two-minute intervals throughout the periods of 7.00 am to 9.30 am and 5.00 pm to 8.00 pm on weekdays; and (b) whether LTA would consider requiring MRT operators to run trains at two-minute intervals throughout these periods in order to reduce overcrowding on trains during morning and evening rush hours.

Mrs Josephine Teo (for the Minister for Transport) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank Mr Giam for his question. Let me first address the question of when to run trains at two-minute intervals. Sir, loading levels today are not evenly distributed across the entire network during peak periods. During the morning peak period, loading levels along the North-South and East-West Line range from 1,350 to 1,420 passengers per train at the heaviest stretches from Bishan to Novena stations, and from Jurong East to Dover stations and this occurs between 7.45 am and 8.45 am. In contrast, average loading at these stretches is about 1,000 to 1,200 passengers per train for the half-hour period before and after this period. Hence, rather than run trains at two-minute intervals for the extended periods as suggested by the Member, current MRT service headways, or intervals between trains, are set to deliver capacity to meet the loading demand, subject to what is achievable under the respective systems.

Page: 557

Let me now turn to the question of constraints. With the completion of the Jurong East Modification Project (JEMP) in May 2011, the infrastructure provisions are sufficient for trains to run at minimum headways of two minutes along the North-South and East-West Lines (NSEWL). The current train fleet only allows one stretch of the network – namely Yishun to Marina Bay along the North-South Line – to operate at two-minute headways for about 45 minutes during the morning peak. Headways at other parts of the network are still slightly longer than two minutes during the morning peak.

To further shorten headways and improve comfort levels for commuters, more trains will be added to the operating train fleet, in tandem with ongoing depot expansion works over the next few years. In addition to the five new trains put into service in May earlier this year, another 17 trains will be added by early next year. This will allow trains to run at two-minute intervals for a longer period across the NSEWL. Another 13 NSEWL trains will also arrive by around 2014 to 2015, and together, these additional 35 trains will enhance the capacity of the NSEWL by about 25%. More trains will also be delivered from 2016 to take advantage of the shorter headways made possible from the re-signalling of the NSEWL.

Besides the NSEWL, new trains are being purchased for the North-East Line (NEL) and the Circle Line (CCL) as well. They will be delivered in about four to five years' time, and are expected to increase the NEL's capacity by up to 50% and the CCL's capacity by about 40%.

Sir, Members may ask why these additional trains cannot be delivered earlier so that commuters can enjoy service improvements sooner. I understand your anxiety and share the same desire for quicker improvements. Unlike buying a car, however, trains cannot be purchased off the rack. Manufacturers do not carry inventories of train cars as trains have to be custom-built to fit the design of the line and platforms. To jump the queue for train purchases is also not possible as manufacturers have to fulfil their contractual commitments to other buyers. In addition, when we plan for additional train purchases, we must at the same time plan for increased depot space and stabling yards to house the trains when they are not in use. In land-scarce Singapore, this poses significant challenges. Notwithstanding these challenges, let me assure Members that we are fully committed to expanding the train fleet in order to improve frequencies of train arrivals.

Mrs Josephine Teo : Mr Giam is very right to point out that there is a significant lead time required to put more trains into deployment. So, to address his question of whether there is advanced planning, the answer is, yes, it has to be the case simply because of the long lead time required to deliver the trains. Projecting demand and ridership ahead of time is always going to be a tricky business. Productivity Measures and Use of Productivity Fund

9 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what is the level of adoption of the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) and other productivity-related initiatives by the SMEs; and (b) how can the Ministry improve on its outreach to help SMEs fully leverage on Government schemes to help them transform and improve productivity to cope with the increase in levies for foreign workers and stricter criteria for S-Pass applications.

10 Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) if he would provide a progress report on the effectiveness of the enhanced National Productivity Fund and the Productivity and Innovation Credit since their inception; (b) how many employers have drawn from them; (c) to what extent has productivity in these companies improved as a direct result; and (d) whether the effects translate to better wages and working conditions for workers.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) : Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, may I take the next two questions together?

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme was introduced in Budget 2010 and significant enhancements to the scheme were made in this year's Budget. We expect businesses to make their first PIC claims when they file their annual income tax returns by November this year. Based on the tax returns that have been filed with IRAS so far this year, about 9,800 companies or 20% of the companies that have filed their returns already had claimed PIC benefits.

So, it is a little too early to say what the take up will be for the PIC scheme. But I can say that IRAS has been putting tremendous effort into promoting the PIC scheme, and especially to SMEs. Just to give Members a feel of the scale, IRAS has sent brochures explaining the scheme to all companies, more than once, and conducted 130 seminars for some 19,000 participants. It is also working very closely with the Enterprise Development Centres and the various Chambers and trade associations to have one-on-one consultations with companies.

Page: 561

As for the National Productivity Fund (NPF), about $600 million has been committed for productivity initiatives over the first five years, starting from 2010. The National Productivity and Continuing Education Council (NPCEC) has identified 12 fairly broad priority sectors to focus its efforts. These comprise a significant chunk of the economy − about 40% of our GDP and 50% of the workforce. We are, in fact, in the process of extending our reach beyond these 12 sectors to more sectors of the economy. For the 12 sectors, productivity roadmaps have worked out for each of them and most of them have already been endorsed by the NPCEC.

Besides these sectoral initiatives with roadmaps for each of them, the NPCEC has also supported a number of "horizontal" initiatives that cut across sectors. One example is the iSPRINT scheme, which incentivises SMEs to adopt information and communications solutions. So far, in fact, about 2,000 companies have benefited from this scheme since it was started last year. These are cross-cutting initiatives that, hopefully, will raise productivity across sectors.

Some examples of how the National Productivity Fund has benefited companies and workers include the following:

First, the construction sector, which traditionally is a labour-intensive industry − about 900 companies have already received help to adopt new technologies, build up capabilities and train workers. For most of the other projects which are in progress, productivity improvements of at least 20% are expected upon completion of the project. Some companies, in fact, have larger improvements of up to 70%.

Second, the Inclusive Growth Programme (IGP), which I think many Members are familiar with, aims to improve the skills and wages of some 25,000 low-wage workers. Twenty-six million dollars has been committed to some 450 projects so far, covering 21,000 local low-wage workers. Two-thirds of the workers involved in these projects are expected to see their wages rise by at least 10% when the projects are completed. This 10% wage increment is over and on top of the regular increments that companies would be expected to give their workers. The training that these workers receive from the projects will also help them to perform higher value-added jobs in future.

Raising awareness and improving the access of SMEs to the productivity schemes − both the tax schemes and the grant schemes − is a continuous effort for all the Government agencies concerned.

Besides the efforts to promote the PIC scheme which I mentioned earlier, SPRING works closely with the Trade Associations and Chambers, the Enterprise Development Centres (EDCs) as well as industry experts and consultants to reach out to SMEs and encourage them to take full advantage of the schemes available. The Trade Associations and Chambers can, in fact, play a larger role in promoting productivity, including devising ways in which their members can collaborate to enhance productivity across the industry. The Government will lend them full support.

Mr Zaqy Mohamad : Sir, I thank the Minister and the Ministry for providing the necessary support to the industries to maximise the PIC scheme. Many of the small companies do not have the kind of business skills or proper HR or finance functions to fully leverage on our schemes. Would the Ministry consider providing funds to build greater capacity for the EDCs and trade associations who could provide proposals on how they could better reach out to some of these companies?

The second question is to ask whether the Ministry would consider reviewing the way we structure some of the productivity schemes in which, sometimes, we ask the companies to spend first and then give them rebates later. Because for smaller companies, cash flow is often an issue. I think that could be a barrier for some companies in considering some of the various schemes.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : On Mr Zaqy's first question: yes, we will consider that. Indeed, some of the trade associations, like the Singapore Manufacturers' Association, are considering ways in which they can help their smaller companies with HR and finance functions, working with cloud computing, for instance, and some other ways. And we are quite prepared to provide support for these initiatives.

On the Member's second point regarding cash flow problems of companies and the companies having to spend first and claim later in fact, we are well aware of that. The cash component of the PIC, which is upfront money and it is designed for that purpose, we are trying to see how the cash component itself can be disbursed as quickly as possible. But if companies know in advance that they are going to get the cash component, they can plan on that basis, and they need is some working capital to tide them over. This is something which we are quite prepared to see how we can improve the disbursement.

Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines) : Sir, the Government has stated its goal of raising the salaries of workers by 30% in 10 years and the key strategy is to improve productivity. Can I ask the Minister how the Government ensures that the various productivity initiatives translate to better salaries and better working conditions for workers, especially for those at the low end whose salaries have stagnated for more than a decade? Does the Government ensure that the companies, which receive the Government's subsidies for these productivity schemes, implement a productivity gain sharing scheme to link productivity performance to rewards for workers and not just add to their own bottomline?

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : I think the Member has quite rightly emphasised the core of our strategy, which is to raise productivity. Together with that, our strategy has to be to ensure healthy economic growth so that the labour market remains tight and unemployment is low, because that is always to the advantage of workers. It improves the bargaining powers of workers when the labour market is tight.

So, these are the fundamental macro strategies – raise productivity across the board and ensure full employment over the next five to 10 years. There will be, of course, downturns from time to time but, on average, we try to keep the labour market as tight as possible. Those two measures in themselves will not be enough, and that is why we have specific initiatives like the Inclusive Growth Programme where we work with companies and industries to, firstly, upskill workers in very specific ways and work with the companies to ensure that the benefits do flow down to workers. So, the example that I gave earlier on the funding that we are providing for the Inclusive Growth Programme comes with some measurable outcomes that the companies are committed to. I gave Members the example of how we expect the workers to get at least 10% wage increment on top of the normal wage increments. With the upskilling, with the improved technology, we expect wage improvements. It does not come automatically. It also comes through coordinated action like the example I gave – Inclusive Growth Programme. There are some other initiatives which we are also working on in the same vein.

Mr Ang Hin Kee (Ang Mo Kio) : I thank the Minister for his reply. Recently, I met an SME from the food manufacturing industry. Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : First of all, if a company does succeed in improving productivity and reducing its manpower requirements, it will allow itself more scope even within our existing quotas for foreign and local workers. It allows itself a little more scope to get foreign workers by virtue of having reduced its manpower requirements. But there is a problem in trying to hardwire productivity improvements to our schemes. What is the baseline? Would you discriminate in favour of a company that was previously inefficient and then did something to become efficient against a company which has already done something to become efficient? So, it is extremely difficult to get into that act of discriminating. Companies that have done a good job of investing all along in raising productivity, reducing the manpower requirements, should not be disfavoured in our rules on foreign labour allocation.

As for the last part of his question, we are looking into this generally when it comes to Government outsourcing, whether we can ensure higher standards on the part of the companies that are obtaining Government outsourcing contracts that involve fair employment conditions, what they are going to invest in productivity, and so on.

Care for the Growing Elderly Population

11 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Health (a) whether he would provide an update on how the Government will help create an environment to care for Singapore's growing elderly population; and (b) whether the Ministry would consider more home-based healthcare services or retirement villages as options for our elderly to age and be cared for gracefully.

Page: 564

The Minister for Health (Mr Gan Kim Yong) : Mr Speaker, the key role of the Ministerial Committee on Ageing is, indeed, to facilitate ageing-in-place, that is, to enable seniors to age gracefully and be cared for at home where they live for as long as possible.

In Singapore, the majority of our population lives in HDB estates. As such, as the HDB population ages, we already have "naturally occurring retirement communities" in our public housing estates.

The key challenge is therefore how to retrofit and integrate care services into our mature HDB housing estates to help seniors age in place. We aim to achieve this in a number of ways. First, we will make our flats and towns more senior friendly, such that seniors can lead independent, active and meaningful lives. The Marine Parade pilot project is a first step in this direction, where we are testing out intra-flat retrofits and improving town infrastructure to make it easier and safer for seniors to move around. The outcomes of our test bed at Marine Parade will help us devise strategies to scale just programmes to the rest of Singapore.

Second, we hope to diversify and enhance the range of care options, especially home help, home medical and home nursing services, such that seniors can be cared for at home even when they are frail or when they fall sick. As we enhance the range of home care services, we will also review our subsidy framework to keep home care affordable. We will also look into ways to enhance centre-based services, such as day rehabilitation facilities and locate them conveniently in the community for better accessibility. Notwithstanding, we recognise that there will still be seniors who may require more intensive care at least for certain periods of time. Therefore, we will also continue to enhance institutional care such as nursing homes, especially for those who need such services.

Third, we want to support those who care for seniors in the homes. We hope to step up efforts to empower caregivers with the proper skills and make respite care, emergency services and counselling support services more accessible.

Our society will age significantly over the next 10 to 15 years, and we need to start to invest in infrastructure and services now to support ageing in place as the need for aged care will grow in the future. The Ministerial Committee on Ageing aims to release a masterplan sometime next year, which will detail initiatives to facilitate ageing-in-place. The Committee will work with various stakeholders to achieve our vision of making this a city for all ages and one which empowers seniors to age in place. We need to work with the private sector and voluntary welfare organisations to scale up our services and to professionalise aged care. We need to work with grassroots organisations and VWOs to outreach and support seniors, especially those who may live alone and have no children to support them. Above all, we need to work with all Singaporeans to support, care for and be gracious to seniors living among us.

Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah) : Sir, I thank the Minister for his comprehensive reply. I have two supplementary questions. The first is, given the manner in which the population demographics is going to change in favour of the number of seniors in Singapore over the next 10 to 15 years, would the Minister consider recruiting a lot more geriatricians for our hospitals and the specialist practices that come with the geriatricians? Secondly, the Minister mentioned respite care and help to support those who are giving care at home. Those are very local home-based support services. While I welcome them, would the Minister also consider community-based support that the elderly can go and receive therapy from each other in form of social interaction within communities?

Page: 565

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Sir, the short answer to both questions is, yes. From the hospital's point of view, we will have to recruit more geriatricians as well as nurses and allied health professionals who provide physiotherapy as well as other related therapies. The medical support staff that will support our ageing population is an area that we will look at. Within the Ministerial Committee on Ageing, for example, there is a sub-committee specifically looking at manpower needs and manpower development to support our various infrastructure development that will be coming on-stream.

The second query on community-based support: yes, indeed, we are looking at how we can create more facilities within the community so that our seniors can go to for therapy, for treatment as well as for health screening. One of the initiatives which we recently announced was the setting up of community health centres where we provide therapy as well as health screening for our senior citizens, not just senior citizens but the population in general. Senior citizens will have better access to them because they are in the community and not necessarily in the hospitals. These facilities will help seniors who are cared for at home because in the day time they can go to these facilities for services or support.

In addition to homecare, as I mentioned in my reply, we will also continue to look at how we can expand the capacity for nursing homes because over time, we will also require more bed capacity for seniors who cannot be cared for at home and need to rely on institutional care. We are looking at different care options for our senior citizens so that we will have a variety of options that will suit the needs of different profiles of senior citizens.

Ms Tin Pei Ling (Marine Parade) : I thank the Minister for the comprehensive reply and I am also heartened that there is a continuous strive towards achieving "ageing in place". But apart from putting in place a conducive environment, infrastructure and programmes to support the care for our elderly, the caregivers' ability to care remains important. Mr Gan Kim Yong : I think Ms Tin has put forward a very important idea of caring for the caregivers because these caregivers who are spending their time and effort, making sacrifices to look after their seniors, their elderly, their frail at home, it is important for us to ensure that they also receive the necessary support from the Government and from the community. That is why the overall masterplan for the Ministerial Committee on Ageing will also include how we can help and support these caregivers, providing some respite in terms of the services that are provided to them or in looking at whether we can provide them with more leave so that they can have more time to look after their elderly and frail at home. Tax on Junk Foods

12 Dr Chia Shi-Lu asked the Minister for Health whether the Ministry would consider (i) a tax on junk foods that contain excessive amounts of sugar and/or saturated fat; and (ii) using the revenue raised for health promotion activities or to subsidise the cost of basic foodstuffs for needy Singaporeans.

The Minister of State for Health (Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan) (for the Minister for Health) : My Ministry has explored introducing taxes on food high in sugar and saturated fat as part of a strategy for addressing the rising problem of obesity in Singapore.

Countries like the USA, Denmark, France and Canada have introduced taxes on sugared beverages whilst Denmark became the first country to introduce a tax on food high in saturated fat just this October. However, we are cautious about introducing similar taxes in Singapore. It is early days yet. First, there is not yet any international consensus on the effectiveness of taxation as an obesity control measure. There is not much clear evidence to show that such taxes decrease the rates of obesity. Second, there may be unintended consequences. Such taxes will raise food prices which disproportionately affect Singaporeans with lower income who spend a greater proportion of their income on food. My Ministry will continue to study the impact of such taxes in other countries. We will also monitor the levels of saturated fat and sugar in our food supply and consumption pattern through regular surveys.

Page: 567

For now we will use other ways to achieve the aim of promoting healthy eating among Singaporeans. The Heath Promotion Board (HPB) is stepping up its effort to do so. Foods that are lower in sugar and saturated fat content are available under the healthier choice symbol, HCS programme. HPB is working with AVA on regulation of trans fat in Singapore. In addition HPB works with food manufacturers and hawker centres to make healthier foods affordable to consumers. HPB is also collaborating with the industry to research and develop healthier foods to its newly established Centre of Excellence for Nutrition.

I would like to assure Dr Chia that we have sufficient funding for health promotion programmes, both at the national level as well as locally. There are also various assistance schemes to help low-income families, such as the ComCare Fund administered by the CDCs.

The Minister of State for Manpower (BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Member for the question. In Singapore, discriminatory employment practices are addressed by the Tripartite Alliance for Fair Employment Practices (TAFEP). TAFEP was set up in 2006 by the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) and the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) with the support of the Ministry of Manpower. Recognising that the key to dealing with discrimination issues is to change employers' mindsets, TAFEP takes a promotional and educational approach to encourage fair employment practices.

With increasing awareness of TAFEP's role, 50 discrimination complaints from job seekers were received in 2008, 72 in 2009 and 119 in 2010. During these years, the main complaints reported by job seekers were those relating to language/race and age. The other complaints were related to gender, family status, religion and others. Towards the end of 2010, TAFEP started to see more complaints centred on Singaporeans' concern over employment opportunities and career development in relation to the recruitment of foreign manpower and talent.

So far, employers approached by TAFEP where it believes that there may be a basis to a complaint, have heeded TAFEP's advice and made adjustments to their employment practices, for example in recruitment. Any job seeker who encounters employment discrimination may approach TAFEP for advice and assistance.

However, A&E departments serve patients who have critical, life-threatening medical conditions or have suffered accidents that require emergency attention. It is a safety net to save lives and therefore we have to keep charges simple and affordable. We need to ensure that patients will get the vital emergency treatment they need.

A&E services are therefore subsidised at 50% at a flat attendance fees imposed regardless of nationalities. In the last five years, the A&E departments in our public hospitals served about 780,000 patients a year. Singaporeans make up the vast majority. Many of them come for A&E for a very short while because they are critical, once they are fixed up and treated, they are discharged. So the time that they spend in the A&E is very short. We do not really want to impose additional administrative burden on the A&E department having to deal with this group of patients, as they need urgent attention.

While we take into account Mr Baey's sentiment, we would like to still keep our A&E departments streamlined and focused on treating the patients, ensuring that everyone who comes to A&E receives emergency treatment that they will need. I think in terms of subsidies, for Singaporeans, those who really cannot afford it even with the 50% subsidy, we will continue to look at other ways because they are with us longer, they are still in Singapore. Even if they are discharged, we will then discuss how they can pay for the costs of A&E. If they really cannot afford it, Medifund will be able to help them over and above the subsidy that has already given in A&E. So, there is already some form of means testing for additional subsidy but for the basic tier of 50% subsidy I think it is better for us to keep the system simple. Telecommunications (Amendment) Bill

3.10 pm

Order for Second Reading read.

The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Sir, the Telecommunications Act provides the Infocomm Development Authority the power to regulate the Telecommunication Act in Singapore. Amongst others, it empowers IDA to grant licences, issue codes of practice and set standards of performance. The Act seeks to establish a robust regulatory framework that promotes and preserves a vibrant and competitive telecommunication sector.

Page: 572

Sir, the Act was last reviewed in 2005, and it is timely for us to review it again to ensure its relevance to the fast-evolving telecommunication landscape. Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed amendment to the Act broadly covers six areas. I will go through each of them in greater detail.

First, amendments provide the Minister with the power to issue a Separation Order for the transfer of telecommunication assets or business of a licensee to a separate entity. This serves to eliminate barriers to competition created by the control of bottleneck infrastructure or the possession of significant market power by vertically-integrated telecommunication licensees. In the telecommunication market, a vertically-integrated operator controls the network infrastructure as well as concurrently participates in the wholesale and retail services markets may not have the commercial incentive to open up these services to its competitors. They may even discriminate against them to gain an unfair advantage for itself. Therefore, remedies such as separation are increasingly being considered and used in other jurisdictions such as the European Union and Australia, to ensure equal and open access to key network elements and services.

Sir, I would like to assure businesses that it is not the Government's intention to exercise the power of Separation Order frivolously. As far as possible, the Bill provides clear conditions and limitations under which a Separation Order can even be considered. Moreover, should the Minister issue the order on an ex ante basis, he may only do so as a "last resort" after having considered the effectiveness of other existing and potential regulatory measures and found them insufficient to enhance competition in the industry. In such a case, the Bill allows the possibility of compensation to the affected licensee.

Sir, the second set of amendments empowers the Minister to issue Special Administrative Orders (SAOs). An SAO is an order from the Minister directing the takeover of control of a telecommunication licensee's affairs, business and property by another person, so as to ensure that a key telecommunication network or service continues to be functional, for both public and national interest. Currently, section 58 of the Act only provides powers for the Minister to act in cases of public emergency, public interest or public security. In these cases, the Minister may issue directions to licensees to prohibit or regulate the use of, or to require the use or control of telecommunication systems and equipment.

In cases of insolvency and abandonment of the network by a licensee, the Minister does not have the powers to ensure that the telecommunication network or service run by the licensee in question continues functioning, and any disruption to the network or service could result in severe social and economic repercussions. Thus, Sir, the amended Act would enable the Minister to issue an SAO in such events, to ensure operational continuity of key telecommunication networks and services.

Sir, we are mindful that telecommunication licensees may have some concerns over these powers, and we have thus limited the conditions under which the SAO may be issued. These include times when the Minister needs to step in to safeguard public interest, or to ensure the reliability and continuity of key networks and services provided by the Public Telecommunication Licensees or Critical Support Infrastructure operators.

The third set of amendments revises the maximum administrative financial penalty to 10% of the annual business turnover for licensable services of a licensee, or $1 million, whichever is higher. This is to ensure that the penalty framework continues to act as a sufficient deterrent to secure licensees' compliance to regulatory conditions. The adjustment of the penalty ceiling is in alignment with other domestic laws such as the Electricity Act, the Gas Act and the Competition Act.

Page: 573

Notwithstanding the higher penalty ceiling, the actual quantum of penalty imposed by the IDA will continue to be based on the facts and severity of each case in the event of breaches of regulatory conditions. In addition, Sir, the Bill also proposes to give IDA the power to cancel or suspend either part of or the whole licence, or reduce the period that the licence is to be in force, should a financial penalty not be paid within the specified period. IDA will do this by giving notice in writing to licensees, without payment of any compensation.

Sir, the fourth set of amendments concerns compliance with the Code of Practice for Infocomm Facilities in Buildings, or COPIF in short. The COPIF requires building or land owners and developers to provide space and facilities, so as to facilitate the roll out of telecommunication services by operators.

Today, any non-compliance with the COPIF is immediately an offence, and the contravener is liable for fines and/or imprisonment. However, Sir, the COPIF does not exist to mete judgement on contraveners as an end, but rather, is only a means to an end to ensure that operators have the necessary space and facilities to provide telecommunication services to consumers in buildings. Thus, the amendments seek to empower IDA to first issue written orders to any building or land owner or developer, who contravenes a provision of the COPIF. This will allow IDA to take into consideration the different circumstances faced by building or landowner or developer before making any non-compliance with the COPIF an offence. With this approach, the IDA will have greater ability to secure compliance with the COPIF, which will in turn ensure efficacy in the deployment of telecommunication systems in buildings.

The fifth set of amendment seeks to update the consolidation framework. This is to account for new concepts relating to mergers and acquisitions as well as new business models that have emerged. These concepts such as voting shares and holdings of associates have been incorporated in legislations such as the Companies Act, the Banking Act, the Electricity Act and the Postal Services Act.

On a related note, the current regime provides for penalty to be imposed on an acquiring party which is a Designated Telecommunications Licensee or DTL, should it fail to comply with IDA's direction to divest its voting shares in another DTL. Going forward, the Bill proposes to extend the regime to cover acquiring parties of DTLs which may not be DTLs of themselves.

The sixth broad area of amendments clarifies the rights and privileges of a Public Telecommunications licensee or PTL. The existing legislation allows for a PTL to enter land to install and maintain his telecommunication installation or plant in such land. The modifications serve to provide clarity over the privileges of a PTL with respect to rights to enter land and buildings to deploy telecommunications systems.

With new industry structure as the Next Generation Nationwide Broadband Network or NGBN, it is necessary to clarify the privileges accorded to the PTLs, to ensure that PTLS enjoy statutory protection of their telecommunication installations and plants regardless of which layer of the industry they operate in. Thus, the Bill also clarifies the rights of a PTL in the case where telecommunication infrastructure is transferred from one PTL to another.

Page: 574

Sir, other than those I have mentioned in detail, there are other more straightforward amendments proposed in the Bill. These amendments serve to clarify IDA's regulatory purview extends to all telecommunication network and equipment even if they are used for broadcasting purposes. We also clarify IDA's powers in governing the number of allocation framework and the licensing of satellite of orbital slots. The Act would also be amended to cater for the service of documents using new forms of communication in addition to registered post and other means allowed today. This will include facsimile transmission and electronic mail.

Sir, in conclusion, the proposed amendments serve to enhance the powers for MICA and IDA to promote and preserve the competiveness of the telecommunication sector and serves to ensure a continuity of key telecommunication network and services. The amendments also seek to update the regulatory framework in line with industry developments such as new industries and company structures.

These changes, Sir, taken together, fortify the Telecommunications Act to be a more comprehensive and effective regulatory framework, ensuring a vibrant and competitive telecommunication industry that ultimately benefits consumers. Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

Question proposed.

3.19 pm

Mrs Lina Chiam : Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the aims of the amendments to section 69(C) of the Telecommunications Act to further promote competition in the telecommunication service market, namely, in empowering the Minister to a Separation Order for a telecommunication licence.

Amendment to section 69(B), however, extends the power of the Minister to allow him to order remedial actions on a person who acquires assets, business and shares in a telecommunication licence. Accordingly, the Minister will be empowered to do so if he is satisfied that the person is not fit and proper and that it is not in the national interests to allow the person to continue.

Mr Speaker, can the Minister tell us what is it that has led to this amendment granting him these extended powers? What does he consider to be against the national interests when speaking of the telecommunications industry, if he exercises his new powers? Can the Minister also assure the House that the powers granted to him in this amendment of the Telecommunications Act will not be used other than to promote market competition and to tackle clear and present threats to our national security?

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : Speaker, Sir, I thank the hon. Member for the queries. I would like to assure her that the amendments are meant not to give more powers to the Minister or the Government but to really allow us to regulate the industry to promote competition. So, I would like to assure the hon. Member and other Members of the House that before we exercise the Separation Order, in particular, we will ensure that we have exhausted all other means possible within our powers. The Separation Order is like the last resort where we have to intervene in order to secure the kind of competition we want in the market.

Page: 575

So, the question that was asked was what led to this amendment. It is really because the industry is evolving very, very fast. In fact, we are not the first to do so to adopt such a power. Other countries are considering the legislation. Closer to home, Australia has already amended the Act to force the companies to do voluntarily. I know it sounds like an oxymoron but the idea is to allow companies to do so on their own within a certain time frame. The EU is also considering such powers.

Given the fact that our market is indeed a very vibrant and open market and with new services, new entrants coming into the market, I think it is important for us to be able to ensure that the playing field is level.

What is against national interests? Well, when you have unfair competition, when we know that only one person or one company is able to monopolise the entire sector which is possible through a vertically integrated structure, we would need to take a look at it very closely as to whether it will allow other companies to come into the system.

So, the Government is committed to ensuring that the business arena is fair and level for all entrance into the market to ensure that there is fair competition because, ultimately, we believe that this will drive prices to affordable level for all Singaporeans.

Question put, and agreed to.

Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. – [Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim].

Central Provident Fund (Amendment) Bill

3.24 pm

Order for Second Reading read.

The Minister of State for Manpower (BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Sir, this Bill will amend the CPF Act to provide for the implementation of the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), to provide for voluntary contributions to be made for members by other parties, and for the reversals of certain transfers between CPF accounts, as well as to streamline the administration of CPF matters.

In the Committee of Supply debate in 2010, Minister Balakrishnan, then the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports, announced the SNSS as an initiative to help parents look after the financial needs of their disabled children who are unable to support themselves upon their parents' demise.

Page: 576

The idea for the SNSS and the Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC) originated from the Parents Workgroup on Enhancing the Financial Security of Persons with Special Needs, led by Ms Denise Phua in 2006. The Parents Workgroup recommendations were endorsed and folded into the current Enabling Masterplan 2007 to 2011, which is a five-year roadmap for the disability sector. Besides Ms Phua, other Members of this House have also spoken of the need for the Government to help parents make provisions to take care of their special needs children after their demise. I would like to place on record our thanks to all who have contributed to this Bill.

Parents of children with special needs can today tap on the SNTC to set up trusts for their children. The SNTC allows parents to formulate a trust arrangement and care plan that will guide the disbursement of funds from the trust to meet the needs of the special needs child after the parents' demise. Parents can set up an SNTC trust account with a minimum of $5,000 using cash, and thereafter they can top up the trust account any time with cash or nominate the trust they set up under SNTC as a beneficiary of their insurance policies or CPF savings.

The SNSS would complement the SNTC by providing an alternative savings option for parents. It will be particularly useful for parents who do not have substantial savings outside of the CPF, and for whom avoiding administrative costs is an important consideration.

SNSS will allow parents to arrange for a stream of income for their children using their CPF savings without having to set up a trust. There is no minimum balance to sign up. There is no administrative charge, as costs are kept low by riding on the CPF infrastructure and keeping the scheme simple. Furthermore, the savings can continue to enjoy CPF interest rates, even after the parent's demise.

Let me now explain the legislative changes that will make SNSS possible. Under existing legislation, when a CPF member passes away, his nominees can only receive the deceased member's CPF monies as a lump sum cash payment or as transfers to his CPF accounts. Clause 12 of the Bill amends section 25 of the Act to allow parents to nominate their special needs child to receive a stream of income under the SNSS instead of a lump sum payment upon their demise.

The SNSS will be open to parents of persons with disabilities who are attending or have attended a Special Education School, or who require assistance in at least one Activity of Daily Living (ADL). These are activities such as dressing, feeding, going to the toilet, moving about and so on. When the scheme is in operation, parents may submit their applications to the Centre for Enabled Living (CEL). The amendments to section 25 in clause 12 allow the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports to impose eligibility criteria, and also allow unsuccessful SNSS applicants to appeal to the Minister for MCYS.

Once an SNSS application is approved, the CPF Board will administer the scheme for the benefit of the special needs child, or SNSS nominee. This involves creating nominee CPF accounts upon the parent's demise and subsequently disbursing the monies from the nominee accounts.

Upon a parent's demise, nominee Ordinary, Special, Medisave and Retirement Accounts will be created and maintained as part of the deceased parent's accounts. The nominee accounts will continue to earn the same interest rates as the original CPF accounts. Extra interest of 1% will also be paid on the first $60,000 of the combined amount in the nominee accounts and the SNSS nominee's own accounts, including up to $20,000 from the nominee's own ordinary account. Clause 11(g) of the Bill inserts a new section 20(1D) to the Act to allow for the creation and transfer of funds into the nominee accounts.

Page: 577

Savings that come under SNSS in the parent's Ordinary, Special and Retirement Accounts, or the OA, SA and RA respectively, will be transferred to the corresponding nominee accounts. In the case of the Medisave Account (MA) balances, there are two options. A parent can opt to have them transferred to the nominee MA and thereafter used to top up the SNSS nominee's own MA each month, up to the Medisave Contribution Ceiling, to meet the nominee's healthcare expenses. Alternatively, he can have them transferred to the nominee SA instead, to bolster savings available for living expenses. Clauses 11 and 12 of the Bill set out how funds will be transferred into the nominee accounts, as well as the two options for the treatment of Medisave Account monies.

After the death of the nominating parent, monthly payouts from the nominee OA, SA and RA will commence upon application by the SNSS nominee. Payouts will be made from the lowest interest-earning accounts first. This means that they will be paid out first from the nominee OA, which earns 2.5%, followed by the nominee SA and then the nominee RA, both of which earn 4%.

Parents can then decide the quantum of these monthly payouts when they make their nominations under SNSS. However, should the parent's savings at demise be insufficient to provide a monthly payout for 12 months, the entire balance would be paid out as a lump sum. Clause 11 of the Bill amends section 20 of the Act to set out disbursement arrangements.

Safeguards will be in place to ensure that the SNSS payouts are made to rightful recipients. Payouts will be made directly to SNSS nominees aged 18 and above and to the legal guardians of nominees aged below 18, unless these nominees lack the mental capacity and have donees or deputies appointed under the Mental Capacity Act. In such cases, payouts will be made to the donee or court-appointed deputy. The scheme will be in operation by early 2012 and MCYS will announce how parents can apply soon.

Let me move on to the next amendment relating to voluntary contributions. Currently, the Act allows a member to voluntarily contribute to his own CPF Account. Family members and employers may also make voluntary contributions for their family and employees. However, companies and associations may also wish to make voluntary contributions to a member who is not their employee, for example, a self-employed person, and individuals may want to make voluntary contributions to non-family members. Therefore, clause 5 of the Bill will amend section 13B of the Act to explicitly allow voluntary contributions to be made by any person, including any company or association or body of persons, corporate or unincorporated. This will create more avenues for members to receive voluntary contributions to enhance their retirement and healthcare savings.

Sir, the next area of change concerns selected voluntary inter-account transfers that CPF members may choose to make. This includes the transfer of savings from a member's OA to his SA to earn the higher SA interest rate, and the transfer of savings from a member's OA and/or SA to his MA to meet his medical expenses.

Page: 578

Such transfers are currently irrevocable since they are commitments made by members to enhance their retirement and healthcare adequacy. In return for this commitment, members may benefit from higher interest rates. However, we also recognise that there could be deserving cases that warrant a reversal of the savings transferred. For example, a member who falls into unforeseen financial hardship and difficulties after the transfer, may need the transferred savings to service his housing instalments.

Clauses 9 and 10 of the Bill will therefore amend sections 18B and 18C of the Act to remove the irrevocability condition, thereby allowing CPFB to make such exceptions in allowing reversals in such extenuating circumstances.

Sir, I will now explain the amendment that will allow for portability of Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. The HPS is a mortgage insurance which pays off the outstanding housing loan should the insured member become incapacitated or pass away, thereby giving a member and his family assurance that they will not lose their home. Unlike most private mortgage insurance, HPS coverage is tied to a specific property. Hence, a member's cover under HPS ceases upon the disposal of that property. If the member subsequently purchases a new property, such as when he upgrades, he would need to get a new HPS cover for that new property.

However, at that point, the member might not be in good health when he purchases a new property. In such a case, his new property would be ineligible for cover under HPS, as CPF Board must be satisfied that the member is in good health. This unnecessarily disadvantages the member, compared to his purchasing a private mortgage insurance. Despite his ill-health, he would still be covered by HPS if he had not purchased a new property.

Clause 20 of the Bill will therefore amend section 31 of the Act to empower the Board to waive the requirement of good health for a member, thereby allowing the Board to insure the member under HPS in respect of his new property where the member was previously insured under HPS for his previous property. In cases where the requirement of good health is waived, we will cap cover at the lower of the remaining sum insured of his previous property, or the extent of his liability for the new property. As is currently the case, cover for members whom CPFB is satisfied are in good health will be capped at 100% of the housing loan. Clause 22 will amend section 39 to enable the Minister to prescribe in Regulations the amount of HPS coverage that a member is eligible for.

Sir, the amendments in this Bill will help parents provide for their special needs children, promote voluntary top-ups, allow for greater flexibility to reverse inter-account transfers where deserving, amongst various other changes, including some which clarify and streamline the administration of the CPF Act. These represent yet another step forward in ensuring that our CPF system remains relevant and effective for our people. Sir, I beg to move.

In addition, some people with special needs I know who have, for instance, Down Syndrome or celebral palsy who have never attended a special school all their lives, having been accepted in inclusive mainstream school in Singapore. The second eligibility criterion in the amendment describes mainly disabilities that are fairly physical and severe. Many of us know of people with special needs who are able to wash themselves, clean themselves, move around and feed themselves. Some can even hold down specific types of jobs but they are individuals who too need guidance in money management, employment and need help in making higher order life decisions such as where to live, whom to contact when they are having health issues and even whom to trust.
