Work Injury Compensation (Amendment) Bill

5.00 pm

Order for Second Reading read.

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin : Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Sir, the Work Injury Compensation Act (WICA) is a piece of social legislation that aims to provide low-cost and expeditious resolution of work-related injury claims. MOM currently processes about 12,500 WICA claims each year. Two-thirds of these claims involve minor injuries. In such cases, the employer is liable to pay the injured worker his medical leave wages and medical expenses, upon being notified of the accident. Where the injury is more serious, involving permanent incapacity or death, MOM will ascertain the amount of compensation based on a medical opinion after the injury has stabilised, or upon death.

In 2010, a total of $76.5 million in compensation was awarded for permanent incapacity and death. On top of that, an estimated $20 million was paid out by employers and insurers for medical leave wages and medical expenses for both minor and serious injuries.

Page: 595

Our Ministry last reviewed the then-Workmen's Compensation Act in 2008. The Act was renamed the WICA and its coverage was extended to all workers, compensation limits were increased and processes were streamlined. The amendments contained in this Bill are more technical and intended to improve the operation of the Act. MOM will also be making some amendments to the WICA subsidiary legislation, as part of an overall package of WICA amendments.

The changes proposed in the Bill are based on two key principles. The first principle is to strike a fair balance between compensation for the injured worker and obligations placed on the employer or insurer. The second principle is to ensure that the WICA framework remains expeditious and workers are able to receive compensation promptly.

Balancing the interests of the injured worker and the employer or insurer is critical because WICA is a no-fault regime, similar to other WIC regimes overseas. This means that injured workers will receive compensation as long as the accident occurred out of and in the course of work, regardless of which party was at fault. Therefore, the obligations placed on the employers and insurers in areas such as compensation and liability must necessarily be limited. Injured workers who feel they deserve higher compensation do have the option to file a civil claim, if they can prove negligence of the party they are claiming against. Three of the amendments are based on this principle.

First, MOM will be updating the WICA compensation limits as part of MOM's regular review of WICA compensation. MOM will increase the compensation limits for death and permanent incapacity by about 21% to account for the rise in nominal median wages since the compensation limits were last revised. The revised compensation limits will apply to all workers covered by the Act.

At present, the minimum limits are $47,000 and $60,000 respectively for death and total permanent incapacity, while the maximum limits are $140,000 and $180,000 respectively. With this change, the minimum compensation for death and total permanent incapacity will be increased to $57,000 and $73,000 respectively. The maximum compensation will also be raised to $170,000 and $218,000 respectively.

To illustrate, with the amendments to compensation norms, the family of a deceased 25-year old worker who earned $1,800 a month could receive $170,000, an increase of $30,000 or 21% more than the family would be eligible to receive currently.

WICA also covers medical expenses for work-related injuries. This coverage is capped at $25,000 per accident or for a period of one year from the accident, whichever is reached first. MOM will be increasing the dollar cap on medical expenses from $25,000 to $30,000 to address the increase in industrial accident medical bills since the last review in 2008. The updated dollar cap will cover more than 95% of all WICA claims where hospitalisation is required.

Second, clause 2 of the Bill amends section 3(5) of the Act to restrict compensation in cases involving work-related fights or attempted assaults. MOM currently receives about 20 claims arising from fights a year, of which three quarters are found to be work-related and hence, eligible for compensation. With this amendment, employers will not be liable under WICA to compensate workers who are injured in a fight or attempted physical assault, except in certain scenarios, which I will elaborate later on.

Page: 596

Whilst the numbers are not large, the rationale for this amendment is that while work-related disputes between co-workers may arise from time to time, they should not resort to fights to resolve them, and employers should not have to bear the cost of injury. Singapore is not unique in doing so; there are overseas jurisdictions which restrict compensation for work-related fights.

However, MOM also recognises that workplace fights sometimes occur and there are several scenarios where an employer should remain liable for compensating a worker injured in a work-related fight. For instance, when the injured worker was a victim and did not participate in the fight, or when the worker was injured whilst exercising his right of private-defence, as defined in the Penal Code, or to defend against bodily harm or damage to property. In addition, a security officer who is sanctioned by his employer or principal to break up the fight or prevent the assault will remain eligible for compensation.

The amendment to section 3(5) specifies that workers involved in work-related fights who are injured in these scenarios will continue to receive compensation, while those who are primarily responsible for the aggression do not.

Third, clause 3 of the Bill amends section 4 of the Act to expand the scope of compensable diseases. Currently, diseases are compensable only when they are listed in the Second Schedule, for example, noise-induced deafness, or as a result of a specific accident at work, for example, a nurse getting infected after a needle prick injury. A new deadly flu strain would not be compensable until it is included in the Schedule.

With the amendment, diseases contracted as a result of work-related exposure to chemical or biological agents will automatically be compensable, including new diseases. To make a WICA claim, the worker must still prove that he was more likely than not exposed at work, and not as a result of community spread. The majority of workers would not be able to claim compensation for communicable diseases such as the common flu or chicken pox. However, certain categories of workers, such as healthcare workers, will generally be able to prove that they were exposed because of their work, and will receive compensation for diseases that they contract.

MOM will also be refining the Second Schedule of compensable occupational diseases. The amendments are technical in nature, mainly to update the list of occupational diseases and associated occupations. Examples include replacing the term "industrial dermatitis" with "occupational skin diseases", which has a broader scope, and the inclusion of "diseases caused by excessive heat" as a new occupational disease.

Sir, the second principle is to ensure that the WICA framework remains expeditious. This will enable the injured workers to receive their compensation as promptly as possible after the accident. Dragging out the resolution of claims also causes uncertainty for employers and insurers. Another three amendments are based on this principle.

First, MOM will prohibit work-related exclusion clauses in insurance policies via clauses 5 and 10 of the Bill which amend sections 23 and 45 of the Act, and upcoming amendments to the WIC Insurance Regulations.

Page: 597

While section 23 currently requires employers to have insurance against all liabilities that they may have under the Act, MOM has encountered cases where the WIC insurance policy does not cover critical aspects of the scope of work carried out by the insured company. For example, an insurance policy for a spray-painting company excluding coverage for flammable substances, or an insurance policy for a construction firm excluding coverage for works exceeding one storey in height. Well, this could be due to several reasons: insurers may not have had the opportunity to explain the exclusion clauses fully or employers may have conveniently relied on their agents to secure the lowest quote without fully understanding the coverage.

When a worker gets injured, the insurer will disclaim liability and the employer will have to compensate the injured worker from his own pocket. If employers lack the financial ability to pay compensation, their injured workers may not receive compensation for their injuries. MOM sees about 200 cases a year where insurers dispute liability on the grounds that the work activity that caused the injury was excluded from the insurance policy.

With the amendments to section 23 and the WIC Insurance Regulations, insurers will be liable to compensate injured workers even if such exclusion clauses exist in the policy. Nonetheless, insurers will continue to have the flexibility to recover from the employer any such compensation paid out, if such recovery is allowed for in the insurance policy.

Second, MOM will insert a new section 25E via clause 6 of the Bill, clarifying liability allocation where there is more than one insurance policy in force for the same accident.

Sir, at present, certain industries have the practice of having multiple parties provide insurance coverage for workers. For instance, in construction, the main contractor may purchase a project policy covering all work relating to the project. At the same time, individual sub-contractors may purchase annual policies covering their workers. When there is an accident, the various insurers may dispute liability and claim that the other insurer should cover the accident. MOM sees about 400 such disputes annually. Compensation to these 400 workers is delayed unnecessarily while MOM sorts out which insurer is liable.

So, the new section 25E will resolve this issue by stating that when there are multiple insurance policies covering an accident, the employer's insurer may not object on the grounds that another policy covers the accident. Barring any other objections, this insurer will be made liable to pay compensation. This is consistent with the WICA principle that we hold the employer primarily responsible for work injury compensation.

However, in view of prevailing industry practice in sectors where the main contractor's insurer compensates the injured worker, MOM will allow third parties to pay compensation as long as they convey in writing to MOM the intent to pay compensation on behalf of the employer's insurer, before the notice of assessment is issued.

Finally, clause 4 of the Bill amends section 11 to state that workers who file a common law suit may not subsequently file a WICA claim for that accident more than one year from the accident.

Page: 598

Currently, workers have to file their WICA claims within one year of the accident, unless there are extenuating circumstances. Having a time limit for filing a work injury claim is practised in other jurisdictions such as in Queensland, Australia where claimants have six months to file a claim and a number of US states (for example, Florida, California, Hawaii) where claimants have one year to file their claim. However, claimants who file their initial claim within one year of the accident and subsequently withdraw it, may re-file their claims with MOM at any time after the accident. MOM has processed claims which are re-filed some six years after the accident. This results in uncertainty for employers and insurers, and drags out the resolution of the claim. Claimants may also be tempted to "forum shop" in an attempt to get the maximum compensation for their injuries.

This amendment then provides a fixed timeframe of one year from the accident for claimants to decide if they wish to file either a common law or WICA claim for their injuries. Claimants may switch between common law and WICA within the one-year timeframe, but may not file a WICA claim after that one year if a common law claim was filed. One year should be sufficient time for the injured worker to make an informed decision about his compensation options.

There are some potential claimants who had previously filed a WICA claim for their injuries within one year of the accident, withdrawn that claim for common law, and still have not received compensation for their injuries. To ensure that such workers are not caught out by the amendment, MOM will provide a one-year grace period from the commencement date of this Amendment Bill, for such potential claimants to re-file their WICA claims. After this grace period, these potential claimants may no longer revert to WICA.

Sir, we will also be making some technical amendments to the Act. The first is that clauses 7 and 8 of the Bill amend sections 28 and 29 of the Act, to make clear that enforcement of orders and appeal against orders also apply to orders made by the Commissioner under section 25A. The second is that clause 9 of the Bill amends section 32 of the Act, to clarify that the enforcement of orders against an insurer includes orders made under section 28 of the Act.

Sir, in conclusion, MOM has tried to ensure that this package of WICA amendments is a fair package to all stakeholders involved in the WICA framework. MOM has consulted extensively with various stakeholder groups, such as NTUC, SNEF, General Insurance Association of Singapore, Singapore Contractors Association Limited, Specialist Trade Alliance of Singapore and Association of Singapore Marine Industries since December last year, and we thank them for their inputs and suggestions. As far as possible, we have taken onboard the feedback as we refined and finalised the proposed amendments. We would like to thank them for all their contributions.

The amendments will be effected on 1 June 2012, to give industry sufficient lead time to adjust to the changes. MOM will continue to educate employees on their rights under the Act as well as organise briefing sessions to the various stakeholders to help them comply with the revised legislative requirements. Sir, I beg to move.

Mr Christopher de Souza : Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join this debate.

Sir, I rise in support of this Bill. The Work Injury Compensation Act is designed to provide a simpler, quicker and more cost-effective way to settle compensation claims by avoiding protracted proceedings. The importance of this Act cannot be underestimated, especially insofar as it seeks to protect employees, who are the vulnerable parties in compensation disputes.

Under the common law, the injured worker has to initiate legal actions to claim damages from his employer. To succeed, the claimant has to prove that the employer had been negligent and therefore held liable. He will need to gather sufficient evidence to prove his case. These obstacles – the financial means required to take out legal claim, the burden of proof that rests on the claimant – are not easily surmountable, often placing the employee in an unfavourable position in relation to his employer. This is not helped by the fact that the employer-employee relationship may be an unequal one.

In contrast, an employee claiming under the Act is not required to prove that the employer is at fault. He only needs to show that his injury was sustained in the course of work. This greatly reduces the burden on the employee and goes towards ensuring his interests are protected against errant employers. A necessary corollary of the discussion centres on the compensation system itself and, in particular, the prescribed compensation limits under the Act.

As part of ensuring that the WICA framework continues to strike a fair balance between compensation for employees and obligations placed on employers, the system must be constantly reviewed and refreshed to be kept in tandem with the ever-changing employment landscape. In line with the stated rationale behind the Act, it is imperative that compensation norms be updated to keep pace with wage increases and changing circumstances. So I would urge the Ministry of Manpower to keep pace with wage increases and changing circumstances where the compensation mechanism is concerned. This would include regularly reviewing the cap on medical expenses so as to keep in step with rising healthcare costs. The bottomline is that the Government must continue to keep abreast of the quantum of awards given so that the compensation system currently in place can retain the requisite maximum flexibility to do practical justice to the parties concerned.

Looking at this amendment, I recall the Court of Appeal's decision in Pang Cheng Suan v Commissioner for Labour (2008), where the workman was allowed to reinstate the WICA claim after more than one year had elapsed. This was a case under the old Workmen's Compensation Act (WCA), but the same provisions have been retained in WICA after the 2008 amendments. What happened was that the workman was injured when a cylinder exploded. He filed a claim under the then WCA and then withdrew it and started a civil suit. Subsequently, a coroner's inquiry into the accident found that the fault probably lay with the cylinder's manufacturer. This made it very difficult for the workman to succeed at common law, as he had to show that his injury was caused by his employer's negligence. He then reinstated his WCA claim, but more than one year had elapsed. The Commissioner rejected his claim for being out of time. However, the Court of Appeal found in the workman's favour. It pointed out that "Parliament recognised that an injured workman would have foremost in his mind the quantum of compensation or damages he was entitled to recover in deciding whether to take up a common law action or to make a claim under the Act. €¦ [The Act], in a way, was not intended to penalise the workman for choosing to commence a common law action in preference to Workmen's Compensation which was invariably lower than damages." Under section 11(4), a workman could reinstate his claim after more than one year if the failure to do so in time was occasioned by "mistake, absence from Singapore, or other reasonable cause." The Court of Appeal held that "reasonable cause" should be given an expansive meaning and one that gave effect to the objective of the Act in providing compensation to injured workers as a first or last resort. Pang's decision to seek a higher recovery of compensation for his injuries at common law was by itself a reasonable cause under section 11(4) of the Act, especially when the Act itself specifically allowed him to do so, and when his employer and the insurer had suffered no prejudice, and their liability under the Act had crystallised.

For example, employers are currently not liable under WICA to compensate employees who are injured as a result of wilful or self-destructive behaviour.

In terms of prohibiting work-related exclusion clauses, Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked how MOM would enforce a prohibition of work-related exclusion clauses and ensure that the injured workers are not denied compensation. The regulations will be revised to prohibit all work-related exclusion clauses in the WIC insurance policies, thereby assuring the injured worker of compensation. However, insurers can contractually require that any such compensation paid out can subsequently be required from the employer. Employers should, therefore, review the terms of insurance policies carefully so that they are not caught unawares of such recovery clauses or lapses in coverage.

I would also like to thank Mr Yeo for his suggestion to stipulate a minimum amount of insurance an employer has to purchase to fulfil their obligation under WICA. Whilst MOM has not encountered instances where insurers provide partial indemnity for work injury compensation, we intend to amend the WICA insurance regulations to pre-empt potential inadequacy in insurance coverage. The regulations will be amended to require that the coverage of WIC insurance policy may not be less than the maximum compensation payable under the Act.

Page: 610

Mr Yeo also suggested that MOM extend compulsory insurance coverage to higher-income earners. Our experience shows that generally higher-income earners tend to incur fewer injuries at the workplace due to their nature of work. As such, we do not think that it is necessary to extend the coverage of mandatory insurance. It is better to leave it to employers to decide with their employees how their risks should be covered. I understand that employers are already buying insurance for this group voluntarily, and MOM sees close to 95% of claims involving these higher-income earners being covered by insurance.

Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef suggested amending WICA to compensate for mental trauma injuries and to compensate heart attacks where they are induced by unexpected strain or over-exertion. Currently, both post-traumatic stress disorders and heart attacks are compensable under WICA, if they result from an accident arising out of and in the course of employment. MOM will investigate such injuries, taking into account the expert opinion of doctors, to determine if they are compensable.

Mr Patrick Tay also asked about the safeguards in place to ensure that workers who suffer death or permanent incapacity from chemical and biological agents after one year are not unfairly penalised. The reason for the time limit is to cap the liability of employers as it would not be fair to impose unlimited liability on employers, given that WICA is a no-fault regime. This one-year time limit is consistent with existing time limits for occupational diseases listed in the Second Schedule. If the worker was diagnosed after the one-year time limit, the injured worker has the option to seek damages under common law. Low-wage workers may also apply for financial aid from the Workers' Fund administered by MOM. In terms of medical treatment or the limits set in place, WICA seeks to strike a fair balance between compensation for employees and the obligations placed on employers and their insurers. MOM has to set a clear limit on the payment of medical expenses in order to provide certainty for employers and insurers. The new limits for medical expenses will continue to fully cover more than 95% of claims where hospitalisation is required. The one-year cap is also quite adequate as most injuries typically stabilise within a year from the accident. Employees who wish to claim the full medical expenses beyond the cap can choose to do so under common law. Needy cases can also approach the hospital's medical social worker for assistance on a case-by-case basis.

Mr Yeo and Mr Patrick Tay asked about the number of cases which were delayed because of workers switching between common law and WICA, and if the amendment would have expedited injury claims significantly.

As I have explained, MOM has seen a significant increase in the number of claims being re-filed more than one year after the accident, with some claims being re-filed some five to six years after the accident. With this amendment, injured workers will have one year to make a considered decision on their compensation options. We think this is a reasonable period of time because WICA – apart from being a no-fault regime - cannot provide unlimited flexibility to allow injured workers to switch between WICA and common law at any time.

Mr Yeo and Mr Tay also asked how MOM would ensure that workers are not disadvantaged by this amendment, particularly since a common law claim may take more than one year to conclude. Both Members may wish to note that injured workers who are unsuccessful at common law are not without recourse. An injured worker who is unsuccessful at common law, can request that the courts assess the WICA compensation due to him minus costs, and direct the employer to pay compensation. However, it helps if workers are clear about their choices and consequences when they decide to opt for a common law suit rather than WICA. It is important to understand that the landscape includes both WICA as well as recourse under common law.

Page: 611

In this regard, Mr Zainudin Nordin and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang have suggested providing workers with independent advice on the compensation options available to them. MOM currently provides assistance to WICA claimants through a variety of means. These include making information on the WICA claims process more accessible, including through flyers in hospitals, and letters to claimants. We also provide claimants with the contact details of their case officers so that they can reach them directly if they need help or clarity on the process. Having said that, I agree with Members that we can and should constantly strive to do better to assist workers. And we have taken note of Members' suggestions and will work with stakeholders on improving the way workers receive advice on compensation claim matters.

Mr Zainudin also cautioned against pressuring workers to settle their claims and Mr Yeo has also pointed out that workers sometimes feel that they have no choice but to seek legal representation to settle their claims. I would like to state that legal representation is not necessary to file a WICA claim. Members can also take comfort and have the assurance that MOM does not pressure workers to settle their compensation claims just to close a case quickly. We do need to pay attention to and be careful of ambulance chases. But, I will reiterate, there is no legal representation required to file such claims.

I would like to thank Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef for her suggestion to clarify when a worker can be compensated if he is injured coming to or going home from work. Currently, WICA already explicitly provides compensation for workers injured when they are travelling on employer-provided transport. There is no requirement for the employee to be performing tasks connected with his employment during the commute or for the route to be inherently dangerous, for the injury to be compensable.

I would like to add that foreign domestic workers (FDWs) are not covered under the Act. Foreign domestic workers are employed by households and typically work and live in the same premises. As a result, it will be difficult to determine whether any injury sustained in the premises was due to work-related activities or otherwise. While FDWs are excluded from WICA, they are still protected under the Personal Accident Insurance that every employer is required to purchase for his foreign domestic worker. The Personal Accident Insurance has a wider scope of compensation than WICA. It provides compensation regardless of whether the accident was work-related.

Mr Yeo Guat Kwang also asked MOM to give special priority to resolve the issue of injured foreign workers staying in Singapore whilst awaiting the outcome of their claims. We will continue to provide targeted assistance, such as through the Public Transport vouchers and the ComCare Fund, as well as through various work support schemes. This approach ensures that those who are really in need of assistance will receive it, and also makes the best use of public funds.

Stricter Quota for Foreign Workers and S-Pass Requirements

(Impact on companies)

35 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower (a) what is the impact of the stricter quota for foreign workers and S-Pass requirements on companies in Singapore; (b) which are the sectors that are most affected by the changes and whether our companies, especially the local SMEs, are able to cope with the changes; (c) whether the tightening of foreign labour has translated into more employment opportunities for Singapore citizens; and (d) whether more from the inactive workforce have been sufficiently engaged to bridge the workforce shortage.

Page: 615

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : The gradual tightening of our foreign worker policies has been effected principally through an increase in levies. We have not adjusted the overall Work Permit Dependency Ratio Ceilings (DRCs) or the S-Pass sub-DRC. Companies which need to hire foreign workers for their operations or for expansion are still able to hire foreign workers as long as they have the number of locals in their workforce as required by the respective sectoral DRCs. However, in order to moderate the growth of the foreign workforce, especially low-skilled workers, we have been increasing the Foreign Worker Levies for Work Permit and S-Pass holders progressively since July 2010. As announced previously, the levies are being raised in 6-monthly intervals up to July 2013.

These increases in the Foreign Worker Levies are more significant in the Services and Construction sectors, given the greater scope for productivity improvements in these two sectors. In the Construction sector, productivity levels are only one-third that of Japan; while the productivity level of the Services sector is only about 60% of the global leaders.

We recognise the difficulties many SMEs face in recruiting Singaporeans. At recent dialogue sessions between MOS Tan Chuan-Jin and the Singapore Manufacturers Federation (SMa) and the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME), they shared the challenges facing SMEs, such as the increase in business costs partly contributed by the rise in Foreign Worker Levies. Some Members, such as Mr David Ong and Er Lee Bee Wah, also raised similar concerns during the debate on the President's Address last month.

The Government recognises the challenges faced by SMEs and has in fact introduced specific initiatives to help them re-engineer their operations and reduce their reliance on labour. One example is the SME Productivity Roadmap, a joint initiative by WDA and SPRING Singapore. We have also taken into account feedback from the various business associations and made significant enhancements to the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) during Budget 2011 to help SMEs benefit further from the PIC scheme.

SMEs can also approach WDA's career centres located at the Community Development Councils or the Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) to participate in job-matching schemes, post job vacancies on WDA's online job portal, JobsNet, or participate in work trials and job fairs. SMEs can also tap on the HR Capability Toolkit developed by WDA and SPRING, which helps them systematically manage their HR functions. Subsidised training specially designed for HR professionals under the Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) framework is also available for SMEs that want to upgrade their HR capabilities. MOM is exploring other ways to help SMEs meet their needs.

The changes in our foreign manpower framework are aimed primarily at encouraging greater value-add and business growth with the same or less number of workers - this is what the productivity drive is about. With higher productivity growth, Singaporeans should also enjoy higher wage growth. The levies may not lead to increased employment of Singaporeans in every sector, but Singaporeans will ultimately benefit from higher productivity growth. We will continue to monitor the outcomes carefully.

More of our economically inactive workforce have joined the workforce in recent years. Hence, the resident labour force participation rate has continued to increase. Some companies are more successful than others in tapping the economically inactive. MOM has various schemes (such as Flexi-Works! and WoW!) to encourage companies to adopt flexible work arrangements. With greater flexibility at the workplace, individuals will be able to balance family and work responsibilities more effectively, and more economically-inactive Singaporeans will be able to return to the workforce.

Page: 616

Much of the increase in local labour force participation has come from women and older workers. Since the formation of the Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers in 2005, the tripartite partners have been working hard to raise the employment rate of older workers. We have seen positive results, with the employment rate for residents aged 55 – 64 rising to a new high of 59.0% in 2010. The Committee has set a target of 65% employment rate for workers aged 55 – 64 by 2015.

Page: 619

MG [NS] Chan Chun Sing : The number of preschoolers (aged 0 to 6 years) diagnosed with developmental delay or disability is approximately 7,000. For those with developmental delay, some of them would overcome them by the time they are in school. There are about 13,000 children with special needs known to MOE in SPED schools and mainstream primary and secondary schools. Hence, there are about 20,000 children with special needs below the age of 18.

Currently, MCYS and MOE do not have comprehensive income and other data on families with children with special needs. The Centre for Enabled Living (CEL) has started to track children who need the Early Intervention Programme for Infants & Children (EIPIC) run by the Voluntary Welfare Organisations. Based on 1,600 children in EIPIC, about 2% belong to families who have more than one special needs child. Also, based on EIPIC data, some 13% come from the lowest 10th household income percentile, 16% are from the 10th-30th percentile and 20% are from the 30th - 50th percentile 1 . I must caution that these figures come from a small base and are not fully representative. The income levels might also be skewed towards the lower income because EIPIC is run by VWOs and some higher income parents might use private services instead.

I understand and appreciate the Honourable MP's concern. I want to assure her that the Government is aware that families with special needs children face greater costs because of the need for early intervention services, education, as well as care arrangements. This is why Government has provided significant subsidies for EIPIC, integrated child care centres and SPED. Families that have more than one special needs child in EIPIC can get additional financial help on a case-by-case basis.

Let me now address the Member's concerns regarding persons with disabilities who outlive their parents. There are many types of disabilities and for each disability type, there is also a range in terms of severity, which affect their health condition and expected lifespan. The "World Report on Disability" produced in 2011 by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and World Bank reported that the mortality rates for people with disabilities vary depending on the health condition. Thus we cannot be definitive on the expected life span of people with disabilities. However, it is likely that those with learning disabilities, mild Autism Spectrum Disorder, mild intellectual disabilities and sensory impairments have life spans similar to the rest of us and are likely to outlive their parents. Some are also more able to work and live lives similar to us.

There would be a smaller group who will require to be cared for all their lives. The cost of care for such a disabled adult varies, depending on whether he is cared for by family, a maid, at a day activity centre in the community or in a residential home. Cost for a maid is about $600 per month, day care about $800 a month, and that for Homes is about $1,600 per month. Government provides a monthly foreign domestic worker levy concession of $95 per month. Means-tested subsidies for day care go up to $615 per month and for institutional care, it is up to $1,200 per month. This works out to be up to $7,000-$15,000 per annum for the adult disabled from the lowest income tier. While it is difficult to put a single dollar value on Government subsidies, as families can switch between different care arrangements, the subsidies are sizeable. Over and above this, the Community Chest and VWOs also raise funds to help defray costs.

Page: 620

We understand and empathise with parents' concerns. This is why my Ministry formed and acted on recommendations from the Parents' Workgroup led by MP Denise Phua in 2006 and the last Enabling Masterplan Steering Committee in 2007. We have begun to put in place the legal and financial security framework to provide for persons with special needs if they outlive their parents. The Mental Capacity Act passed in 2008 allows parents to appoint trusted persons as decision makers for their mentally incapacitated children when they pass on. The Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC) launched in 2009 provides non-profit trust services and also enables parents to lodge a care plan for their children when they pass on. MCYS and CPF Board are also implementing the Special Needs Savings Scheme, so that parents can use their Central Provident Fund accounts to provide a stream of income to their children upon their demise. The ongoing Enabling Masterplan exercise will look at many issues related to the disabled, including how we can provide better support and care for the adult and ageing disabled and their families.

1 Means-tested subsidy is for the bottom 10th, 10th-30th, and 30th-50th income percentile. We do not have bottom 20th percentile data.

Therapists for Children with Learning Difficulties

50 Ms Low Yen Ling asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the current number of therapists (psychologists, speech and language therapists, physiotherapists and occupational therapists) in public and private sectors who are serving children with learning difficulties in Singapore; (b) what is the current number of children under 18 years old who are diagnosed with learning difficulties; and (c) what is the progress of training and recruitment of manpower in child development that was announced under the $46 million fund for the Child Development Programme.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : The management of children with learning disabilities is a complex issue which requires multi-agency coordination across the social, educational and healthcare sectors. Currently, it is estimated that there are about 22,000 children under 18 years old with learning difficulties. They are assisted by several programmes that seek to develop their potential to be independent, self-supporting and contributing members of society.

Under the Child Development Programme (CDP) (under MOH), child development experts from KKH, NUH and four community-based clinics work together to identify and treat children with developmental problems, including learning disabilities, early, that is, in children from 0 – 6 years old. The programme complements MCYS' and MOE's efforts under the Enabling Masterplan, a national roadmap to chart the direction for the disability sector in Singapore, to help such patients and their families.

Children identified with special needs under the CDP will be referred to centres under the Early Intervention Programme for Infants & Children (EIPIC) or Integrated Child Care Programme (ICCP) (under MCYS) that provide therapy and education support services, depending on the severity of their conditions. Children with special educational needs at school-going age (6 – 18 years) are enrolled in either Special Education (SPED) or mainstream schools. SPED schools run special programmes catering to distinct disability groups of children who are not able to benefit from mainstream schooling. Children with mild learning disabilities enrol in mainstream schools, where additional support is provided to them through Allied Educators or professionals from Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs), such as the Dyslexia Association of Singapore, Singapore Association for the Deaf or Asian Women's Welfare Association.

It is estimated that there is a total of about 230 psychologists and therapists in the CDP, EIPIC, ICCP programmes, SPED and mainstream schools. This includes a total of 36 psychologists, occupational-, speech- and physio- therapists, in the CDP. The injection of $46 million into the CDP has enabled KKH and NUH to increase their child development manpower by more than 65% over the last 3 – 4 years. KKH and NUH will be further enhancing the manpower resources by recruiting trained professionals both locally and from abroad.

Overall, the Government has been expanding its support and programmes to train child psychologists and therapists. For example, MOE has collaborated with NIE to offer a Diploma in Educational Psychology since 2008 to train Associate Psychologists and psychologists from SPED schools and ITE, to equip them with competencies to provide psychological services to schools under the supervision of qualified Educational Psychologists. KKH, together with Parenting Research Centre (PRC), Australia and with the support of the National Council of Social Services (NCSS) and Temasek Cares, started a "Signposts" programme in 2011 to train therapists to be Signposts facilitators, with the objective to equip parents to better understand and manage their children's behaviour. To date, KKH has trained over 70 facilitators, including therapists and social workers, in the 12 EIPIC centres. It has also trained 3 local trainers certified to train others.

In addition, as mentioned by my colleague, Acting Minister Chan Chun Sing, in Parliament last month, MCYS has introduced a new "place-and-train" scheme to allow EIPIC teachers and therapists to be hired ahead of enrolment. This will help expand the capacity of EIPIC more quickly to meet the needs of the growing number of pre-school children diagnosed with disability or developmental delays.

Medical intervention (under the CDP) plays a part in the integrated support for children with developmental needs. But more can be done. With improvements in healthcare and the general standard of living, our population is living and working longer. It is important that we prepare employers and workers for an ageing workforce. Hence, the Tripartite Committee (Tricom) on Employability of Older Workers, which comprises representatives from unions, employers and the Government, was set up in 2005. One key indicator monitored by the Tricom is the employment rate of older workers aged 55-64. Through the concerted efforts of tripartite partners, the employment rate for this group of workers reached a new high of 59% last year. The Tricom has set a target of 65% employment rate for workers aged 55-64 by 2015.

To achieve this, we need to ensure that our workers have the opportunity to work longer. Today, the statutory minimum retirement age is set at 62. When the re-employment legislation takes effect from January next year, employers will be required to offer re-employment to employees once they reach age 62, until age 65, so long as they are medically fit to continue working and have satisfactory work performance. This is an additional layer of protection for older workers to help them continue working if they wish.

MOM takes a serious view of discrimination against any employee, including that of age discrimination. If an employee feels that he or she has been unfairly dismissed on grounds of age, he or she can appeal to MOM for reinstatement or compensation.

Persuading employers to adopt non-discriminatory recruitment practices requires a change in their mindset. The tripartite partners have issued the Tripartite Guidelines on Fair Employment Practices to promote the adoption of fair and responsible employment practices, including that of discrimination against older workers. The Tripartite Alliance for Fair Employment Practices (TAFEP), which was established in 2006 with key representatives from unions, employers and the Government, provides a range of services, tools and resources to help organisations implement fair employment practices. TAFEP also looks into feedback and complaints on workplace discrimination issues.

The Ministry will continue to work with our tripartite partners to keep a close tab on the labour market situation and to help our older workers secure employment.

52 Mr Liang Eng Hwa asked the Minister for Transport (a) how the Ministry intends to ease the parking shortage situation in the Central Business District; (b) whether the car park shortage in the financial district has impacted our attractiveness to draw global institutions to plant their regional HQ in Singapore; and (c) whether the ratio of car park lots to office space should be reviewed.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : The Land Transport Authority (LTA) sets a minimum parking requirement for each building according to its type of use and Gross Floor Area (GFA). Developers can decide whether to use their GFA to provide parking spaces over and above the minimum requirements. In other words, there is no cap on parking provision. In deciding the additional parking lots to be provided, developers will have to balance the use of their building space in order to maximise their returns and to meet the parking needs of their tenants and customers. Parking charges are also left to the market, as building owners decide on the appropriate pricing in response to demand for parking spaces.

Page: 625

LTA monitors the parking situation through regular parking occupancy surveys. A survey conducted this year for many of the office buildings along the Shenton Way and Raffles Place area showed that there are sufficient parking spaces with an average utilisation of about 70% during peak periods. However, there may be a perception of parking shortage as parking demand is not evenly distributed. The car parks in some buildings are more attractive to motorists due to their location and/or parking charges.

LTA has recently conducted a review of the parking situation in the CBD and will retain the current parking standards.

Going forward, as we implement more MRT lines to encourage travel to the city centre by public transport, the need to drive to the CBD, and hence the demand for parking, should decline further over time.

This trend is consistent with other cities, such as Hong Kong, London and Tokyo, where public transport is the dominant and sustainable mode of travel to their CBDs. These cities have thrived as major financial centres, and are ranked well in terms of economic competitiveness.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : In the past three years, about 800 summonses were issued annually to cyclists for cycling offences committed along roads. The common infringements were: failure to ride in an orderly manner, riding during hours of darkness without a front light or red reflector, and riding a motorised bicycle without wearing a protective helmet.

The Traffic Police takes a strong view against cyclists who flout traffic rules, particularly those who display dangerous cycling behaviour, such as riding without due regard to the safety of others. The Traffic Police will continue to maintain ground presence to ensure that cyclists and other motorists abide by the traffic rules. Stepped up enforcement is also conducted against specific traffic offences and in areas where road accidents commonly occur.

However, enforcement alone is not sufficient. We must also inculcate a safety mindset in cyclists to take responsibility for their own safety and accord due care to the safety of other road users. As such, the Traffic Police continues to engage the community on the importance of safe riding. For instance, it conducts road safety talks and exhibitions at schools, workplaces, worker dormitories, and community events. The Traffic Police also works with the Ministry of Transport and the Land Transport Authority to create a safer environment for cyclists through the development of suitable infrastructure and facilities.

Road safety is a shared responsibility. All road users must play their part by adhering to the traffic rules, and by respecting the rights and safety needs of the different road users. This is the most effective way of reducing both errant behaviour and accidents on our roads.

58 Dr Janil Puthucheary asked the Minister for National Development whether the contracts for the installation and maintenance of solar panels in HDB estates will be awarded to a number of companies via tenders so as to increase the opportunities to gain experience with this technology.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : At the current state of technology, solar energy costs more, watt for watt, than electricity from the grid. However, as the cost of solar energy is expected to fall over time, HDB has embarked on a pilot programme to test-bed the technology and to build capabilities in HDB and the industry.

As this is done on an experimental basis, HDB plans to install solar panels in only 3% of HDB blocks, thus covering only a small percentage of overall electricity consumption. In these pilots, HDB either pays for the installations fully, or subsidises 30% of the upfront cost in a solar leasing model, where private companies own and maintain the solar panel systems. The solar energy generated is then either passed on to the Town Council for free or sold to the Town Council at a subsidised rate by the leasing company to power lighting at common areas, water pumps and lifts. So, while solar energy costs more than grid electricity, the participating Town Councils will enjoy some savings because of the subsidies that the Government provides for this capability building programme.

As technology develops, and when solar energy costs less than electricity from the grid, the systems can be installed more widely and Town Councils will be able to enjoy savings even without subsidy.

Dr Janil has also asked whether the contracts for the installation and maintenance of solar panels in HDB estates will be awarded via tenders to increase the opportunities for companies to gain experience with this technology. Indeed, HDB has been procuring solar PV systems through open tender via Gebiz. Since 2009, HDB has awarded 10 contracts to six local companies. Some of these companies are gaining experience not just locally, but overseas as well. HDB will continue to procure future contracts through open tenders.

Guidelines and Competition in Healthcare Insurance Industry

62 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Health (a) whether insurers are regulated and/or receive guidelines on the extent to which they may exclude healthcare coverage because of applicants' pre-existing medical conditions; (b) whether additional regulation is needed to ensure that insurance exclusions are not disproportionate; and (c) whether the Ministry sees areas for improved efficiency and competition in the market for healthcare insurance.

Page: 628

Mr Gan Kim Yong : My Ministry takes a two-tiered approach towards health insurance. For basic coverage, we encourage as many Singaporeans as possible to be covered under MediShield, which is run by CPF Board and aimed at covering the cost of Class B2/C bills. 90% of Singaporeans are currently covered under MediShield. For those who wish to have additional coverage beyond MediShield, for example, for non-subsidised services, such as Class A or B1 charges, we have allowed the private sector to play a role in meeting this demand, via a range of Integrated Shield Plan and other private insurance products. There is a competitive Integrated Shield Plan market for those who seek higher coverage, with five insurers offering 26 plans targeted for different needs.

MOH does not regulate the underwriting decisions of private insurers and the criteria for accepting or rejecting applicants for Integrated Shield Plans or for imposing exclusions on pre-existing conditions. These are commercial decisions taken by the industry, depending on each insurer's risk appetite and claims experience as well as the profile of the applicants. About 5.5% of Integrated Shield Plan policyholders have exclusions for pre-existing conditions imposed on their coverage. To safeguard the interest of Singaporeans, MOH requires private insurers to be transparent with their clients by keeping their terms and conditions simple and clear. We also require them to guarantee renewals so that policyholders are not dropped even if they fall sick and incur high claims subsequently, and publish the time taken for them to process claims.

We must be mindful not to over-regulate these optional add-on plans. Insurance operates on the concept of risk pooling. If we impose overly stringent conditions on the insurers and compel them to take on higher risk applicants, they may have to raise premiums to meet these conditions. This may not be in the overall interest of the insured.

We share Ms Tin's concern about insurance coverage for Singaporeans with pre-existing conditions. Thus far, our approach has been to bring as many Singaporeans onto health insurance as early as possible before health conditions develop. For this reason, we introduced auto-cover for MediShield at birth in Dec 2007. As a result, we expect the extent of Medishield coverage to increase over time. Besides insurance, heavy Government subsidies in the public hospitals and Medisave savings will help to defray healthcare expenses. Medifund also provides a safety net for needy Singaporeans. We will continue to review our health insurance regulation to ensure it meets our needs.

Measures to Counter Impact of Inflationary Costs

64 Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what measures are in place to help Singaporeans cope with the higher cost of living, especially food prices; (b) whether it will be sustainable for the Singapore dollar to continue its appreciation trend to dampen inflationary pressures, given its impact on the export sector.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : The "headline" CPI inflation figure is expected to average about 5% in 2011. However, the actual cost of living increase for most households is lower than this. This is because the headline CPI estimate includes imputed rentals on owner-occupied homes, which are not actually paid by households. It has also been significantly influenced this year by the sharp rise in Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums, although only a small percentage of households have bought cars this year. Excluding these two factors, the cost of living increase for the majority of Singaporeans is expected to be about 2.1% for 2011.

Food price inflation has averaged 2.9% in the first nine months of the year.

The "Grow & Share" package for Singaporeans that was introduced in this year's Budget more than offsets the increase in the cost of the household baskets for lower and middle income Singaporean households this year. For example, a family of four with two children and earning a combined income of $2,000 will receive about $3,100 in benefits. This is around four times the expected increase in their household expenses this year of about $770. This also does not take into account other permanent benefits that Budget 2011 introduced besides the Grow & Share package, such as the enhanced subsidies for pre-school education and childcare for lower income families, and the removal of the radio/TV licence fees.

Nevertheless, there are needy families who need additional help due to their unique circumstances. They can get help from Comcare and other schemes, and many do so.

The strengthening of the Singapore dollar is a key macro-economic policy tool to keep inflation in check over the medium term. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) continues to recognise the need to strike the right balance between ensuring exporters are not unduly hurt by a stronger currency, and controlling price and cost pressures in the economy. Since April 2010, MAS has had a policy of gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar currency against a trade-weighted basket of other currencies – in other words, of the Singapore dollar Nominal Effective Exchange Rate (NEER).

Page: 630

Taking into account the cooling of global demand and likely moderation in inflationary pressures, MAS has adjusted the Singapore dollar Nominal Effective Exchange Rate (NEER) policy band in October this year to appreciate at a more modest and gradual pace.

Pensions of Retiring Ministers

2 Mr Pritam Singh asked the Prime Minister (a) what is the amount (in monetary terms and detailed component breakdown) of the pension received by each retiring Minister after the 2011 General Election; and (b) whether the aforesaid pension will be reduced retrospectively in light of the upcoming Ministerial pay review.

Mr Lee Hsien Loong : Pensions paid to Ministers are computed in accordance with the Parliamentary Pensions Act. The Government has explained how pensions are calculated on several occasions in Parliament and through media releases.

Ministers have to serve at least eight years as a political office-holder to qualify for a pension. The pension is based not on the total monthly salary, but only on the pensionable component of this salary. The pensionable component has been frozen since 1994, and all salary increases have been added to the non-pensionable component to contain pension costs. Thus, the pensionable component has been decreasing as a proportion of total monthly salary. The annual components of salary (such as the 13th month payment, Annual Variable Component and Performance Bonus) are also not pensionable.

A Minister qualifies for the maximum pension only after having served as an office-holder for 18 years. The maximum annual pension is about 10% of his annual salary prior to retirement. The pension will be less if he has served for a shorter period. The value of the pension that a Minister may receive upon retirement is fully taken into account when ministerial salaries are set against the benchmark.

A Committee chaired by Mr Gerard Ee has been formed to review the salaries of political appointment holders which are to take effect from 21 May 2011. This includes a review of the pensions for Ministers. The Committee has said that it expects to complete its work by the end of this year. The Government will take into consideration the Committee's recommendations when deciding on the pensions for Ministers.

Regulation of Motor Insurance

7 Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance if there can be a review and some form of regulation of motor insurance.

Page: 634

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : I understand Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef is concerned about variations in motor insurance premiums offered by different companies.

The key issue is whether the premiums are being set in a competitive market that offers consumers ample choice. Motor insurance premiums in Singapore are not controlled and determined by the authorities. More than 20 insurers compete to provide motor insurance in Singapore, including two who offer motor insurance online to remove the cost of intermediation. Consumers therefore have a wide range of insurers to choose from. They should obtain quotations from different companies, and shop around for the best price for the specific type of coverage desired. Competitive pricing gives motorists more choices while spurring insurers to reduce cost and customise their products. The amount of motor insurance premiums charged is based on the insurer's assessment of the risk that the policyholder brings to the pool 2 .

Motor insurers may assess these risks differently depending on their business strategy, target market segment, risk appetite and loss experience. This may result in differences in the computation of premium payable, although market competition will ensure a certain amount of pricing discipline. If an insurance company quotes a premium of $10,000 while its competitor quotes $5,000 for a policy that is identical in every manner, then the more costly insurer will lose its market share. On the other hand, if the $5,000 quote is mispriced, this may inevitably lead to the insurer raising its premiums over time to recover its losses.

Of course, for the market to work, consumers must make informed decisions and exercise their choice freely. MAS will continue to use the MoneySENSE national financial education programme and work with the General Insurance Association of Singapore and other relevant stakeholders to educate consumers on motor insurance matters to enable them to make well-informed decisions.

2 Insurers take into account a combination of factors when assessing this risk:

- Make, model, engine capacity and age of vehicle.

- Age, gender, occupation, driving experience and claims history of the driver.

- Use of the vehicle (whether for private use/corporate use/commercial use/hire etc).

- Type of cover (a higher premium is charged for a comprehensive insurance policy compared to a third party policy).

- Level of deductible (As deductible relates to the first amount of each claim which is not covered by the policy and is borne by the policyholder, a lower deductible would mean that the policyholder pays higher premiums for his motor insurance policy compared to another policyholder who pays a lower premium for a higher deductible).

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : A productivity-driven and innovative economy needs a strong and supportive Continuing Education and Training (CET) foundation to ensure that the workforce has the relevant skills to meet current and future needs. Over the years, WDA has developed a robust and comprehensive CET system based on the key tenets that training must meet the needs of employers and also lead to better jobs and improved employability for our workers. E2i is one of the multiple stakeholders in this national CET system.

To-date, about 700,000 workers have been trained in Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) courses 4 . This includes workers who were sent for training by their employers as well as individuals who participated in training on their own initiative. In a 2010 survey, 88% of respondents indicated that they were able to apply the skills learnt from WSQ training in their jobs. Similarly, more than 90% of 1,900 companies surveyed indicated that WSQ training had helped improve the work performance of employees.

WDA has also put in place Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) to enable professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) to switch to a range of new occupations such as registered nurses, occupational therapists, preschool teachers and software developers. As at Dec 2010, about 3,600 PMETs had undergone or were undergoing training.

As training should lead to improved employment outcomes, our CET Centres also provide job placement services. WDA's Career Centres at the Community Development Councils (CDCs) and e2i also play an integral role in placing workers in jobs. Where workers possess the requisite skills, the Career Centres can help to place them into job vacancies on hand. However, where skills gaps are identified, the Career Centres would encourage workers to go for relevant training before placing them in jobs. Six in 10 job seekers were placed into jobs by WDA's Career Centres and e2i in 2010. This translates to some 17,000 successful job placements.

A tight labour market also means that local workers have ample choices of jobs. However, there is also some mismatch of skills, with employers needing skills which those looking for jobs do not have. We have thus been working closely with industry to redesign jobs and train workers to meet the needs of these jobs.

Ultimately, the solution lies in upgrading jobs and productivity, and allowing employees to take pride in their work, no matter what the job. Higher productivity will enable employers to offer better pay and career prospects to local workers.

The Government is investing heavily to support companies and workers in this effort. This includes both generic and focused schemes. Amongst the focused approaches is the Inclusive Growth Programme (IGP) administered by e2i and funded by the National Productivity Fund. The $40 million scheme provides grants to help employers raise productivity by investing in training their workers and by leveraging on technology to reduce reliance on manpower.

12 Mr Pritam Singh asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower in light of reports on the wrongful restraint of foreign workers and their alleged forceful repatriation by foreign worker repatriation companies (a) whether these allegations have been investigated and, if so, what is the outcome of the investigations; and (b) whether the Government has any plans to regulate the activities of such repatriation companies.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : Employers are responsible for the repatriation of their work permit holders upon the completion or termination of the employment contract. Some employers use third parties such as repatriation companies to ensure the smooth and proper exit of their workers. Sometimes, employers also use repatriation companies to house workers in the interim while any claims are being resolved before they are repatriated back to their home countries.

Whether the employer or a third party repatriates the worker, the repatriation of foreign workers must be carried out in accordance with all our laws. That must be clear. Any act to wrongfully restrain or confine foreign workers is criminalised in the Penal Code. The Employment of Foreign Manpower Regulation states that the employer shall ensure all outstanding salaries or moneys due to the foreign employee have to be paid before the foreign employee's repatriation. This includes any work injury compensation that employers are required to pay under the Work Injury Compensation Act.

Page: 639

The government takes seriously all cases where members of the public, workers or NGOs claim that repatriation agents may have breached the law. If the worker is confined, MOM and the Police will ensure that the worker is not confined against his will and that his issues are addressed in a timely fashion. Possible labour or Penal Code offences are thoroughly investigated by MOM and Police respectively, against both the repatriation companies and the employers. As an additional safeguard, MOM has an arrangement with the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) to surface complaints and refer departing foreign employees who express employment grievances at the immigration checkpoints. These employees will then be referred to MOM for investigations.

There are no plans at present to regulate repatriation companies. Potential abuse related to repatriation is already covered under existing legislation and applies to employers as well as third parties. In 2010, an employee from a repatriation company was prosecuted and sent to jail for voluntarily causing hurt to a foreign worker. The employers of the foreign worker were given a stern warning for abetment to wrongful restraint.

The number of complaints made against the handful of repatriation companies has also remained small over the years. Since 2010, MOM and MHA received seven complaints against three such companies, a fraction of the approximately 16,000 non-domestic work permit holders repatriated to their home countries in that time.

Notwithstanding the above, officers from the Ministry of Manpower, Singapore Police Force and Singapore Civil Defence Force have taken proactive enforcement action, jointly inspecting the premises of repatriation companies for breaches to ensure that repatriation companies comply with the law when carrying out their business.

The inspections are an initiative of the Inter-Agency Taskforce on Trafficking-in-Persons, co-chaired by MOM and MHA, to ensure that foreign workers are not victims of labour trafficking being forcefully repatriated to prevent them from making valid claims or complaints against their employers.

While no infringements have yet been uncovered, and foreign workers were found to be allowed free movement in and out of the premises under escort, advisories have been issued to the companies reminding them to abide by the law and refer foreign workers to MOM if there are any outstanding salaries or injury claims owed to the worker.

The Ministry of Manpower recognises that no worker should be forcefully repatriated without his claims being settled. We will work with the Police to look into all such complaints and continue to maintain proactive checks against employers and repatriation companies to ensure they comply with our regulations.

Negotiations have been smooth and constructive thus far, and discussions have covered the entire range of issues typically covered in a high-quality and comprehensive FTA, such as trade in goods and services, non-tariff barriers to trade, Government procurement, competition policy, intellectual property rights and sustainable development.

Page: 641

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : We understand the desire among Singaporean Muslims to go on the haj. Singapore's official quota for the haj this year was 680. In September, we were allocated another additional 1,500 places, following my personal appeal at the Haj Ministerial Meeting in Saudi Arabia earlier this year, bringing the total official places to 2,180. MUIS, the central haj authority in Singapore, allocates these visas based on its Advance Haj Registration System, under which priority is given on a queue basis to first-timers who have not performed haj before.

Since last year, the Saudi Embassy here in Singapore has acceded to appeals from travel agents on behalf of the would-be pilgrims for additional visas. These visas which are outside of the official visas mentioned above are termed goodwill visas.

This year, 652 would-be pilgrims were unable to perform the haj because we were not given any goodwill visas, unlike the previous year. Understandably, the affected people were disappointed. I personally made repeated appeals to the Saudi Haj Minister, including meeting him in Saudi Arabia when I attended their Crown Prince's funeral in end October. Despite these attempts, we were not granted any additional visas.

MUIS' policy is that applicants who are under MUIS' Advance Haj Registration System should be given their visas ahead of those who are to be granted goodwill visas. However, due to time constraints this year, the Saudi Arabia Embassy in Singapore processed applications on a first-come-first-served basis. When they reached our total quota of 2,180, they were unable to issue any more. This resulted in visas being given to some 316 pilgrims from the group of 652 who were supposed to be given goodwill visas. Hence, 316 applicants from MUIS' Advance Haj Registration System who were supposed to be part of the official quota of 2,180 were unable to get visas. MUIS will give priority to these affected pilgrims next year.

As for the remaining 336 goodwill visa applicants who were disappointed this year, whether they will get to perform the haj next year will depend on total number of places given by the Saudi Arabia authorities. Just like what we did this year, we will try our best to secure as many additional places as possible. However, we should respect the official number of places approved by the Saudi Arabia authorities.

MUIS is our central haj authority that works with the Ministry of Haj in Saudi Arabia. It has put in place a comprehensive system that not just processes applications but also includes the provision of medical and welfare services, vetting, validation and appointment of travel agents to provide haj services, training of pilgrims and even certification of those leading them.

We will continue to review and to improve the system. But for the system to work, it is important that all abide by the system, especially for visa matters. I urge General Sales Agents and the Association of Muslim Travel Agents Singapore as well as members of the community who wish to perform haj to adhere to MUIS' registration process and system. This will help prevent this year's problem with the visas from recurring.

Risk of Falling Trees and Branches During Storms

17 Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim asked the Minister for National Development if he will provide an update on the measures taken to assess the condition of trees and the risk of trees and branches falling during a storm.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Last year, there were about 1,400 incidents of tree failures, that is, fallen trees or branches. While this is a sharp drop from about 3,100 cases in 2000, we have intensified our tree management programme as adverse weather is becoming more frequent in recent years.

First, NParks has sharpened its regular inspection of its trees for signs of poor condition, disease, pests or structural defects. It pays particular attention to the larger mature trees, especially those in areas with high vehicular traffic.

Second, NParks has intensified its tree safety inspection, pruning and replacement efforts. Mature trees along expressways and major roads are now inspected once every 12 months and 18 months respectively. Since Sep 2010, NParks has pruned more than 466,000 trees. This has helped to reduce the weight of the foliage, enhancing the trees' stability during rainstorms.

Third, NParks is progressively replacing storm-vulnerable roadside trees with hardy species.

Fourth, NParks is installing instruments in areas prone to flooding and soil water-logging, to monitor the soil moisture, rainfall and wind conditions. Such information can prompt NParks to take appropriate preventive actions, as even healthy trees can also fall during gusty winds and heavy rainfall.

While we continue the concerted efforts to minimise tree failures, we are mindful that with more than 1.3 million trees in Singapore, some tree failures may still happen from time to time.

HDB can help them source for a flat that is within their budget, or extend loans to reduce the upfront cost of purchasing another flat. HDB can also offer them temporary accommodation under the Interim Rental Housing Scheme while they rebuild their savings or work out more permanent housing arrangements. If home ownership is out of reach, HDB can consider offering them a public rental flat.

The 30-month debarment rule is imposed to deter people from selling their flats for cash and applying for the heavily subsidised rental flats. However, HDB goes through each application for rental housing carefully and has waived the rule for the truly needy divorcees who cannot afford other housing options and have no family support.

We will continue to study the housing needs of the low-income divorcees to see what more we can do to help. However, the problems confronting low-income divorcees often extend beyond housing. The larger social problem has to be tackled upstream and will have to involve other Ministries and social agencies for a more complete solution.

Protection from Illegal Moneylenders for Buyers of Resale Flats

21 Dr Intan Azura Mokhtar asked the Minister for National Development what can be done to protect resale flat buyers from bearing the brunt of illegal moneylenders that the flat sellers were involved with and where these sellers made use of the opportunity to borrow from these illegal moneylenders just before selling their flats.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Addressing the problem of a person using a false HDB address or an outdated HDB address to borrow from a loanshark requires cooperation from many parties.

First, the National Registration Act requires Singapore residents to report their change of address to the Police or the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) within 28 days. Failure to do so is an offence and punishable by a fine or imprisonment, or both.

Second, the Moneylenders Act makes it an offence for borrowers who deliberately provide false addresses. They may face imprisonment for up to a year.

Third, HDB requires all flat sellers to provide a valid forwarding address. HDB also requires lessees who sublet bedrooms or whole flat to register their subtenants with HDB. These two measures have enabled the ICA and the Police to follow up on cases where identity card holders fail to register a change in address, or to trace individuals involved in illegal borrowing using their former address.

Prevention of Flooding in Sennett Estate

24 Mr Sitoh Yih Pin asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources what measures the PUB will be taking to prevent flooding in Sennett Estate in light of the expected increase in rainfall.

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan : Sennett Estate is located on low-lying ground and subjected to flash floods during heavy rain. The area last experienced flooding on 5 June 2011, where parts of Siang Kuang Avenue, Jalan Kemboja and Puay Hee Avenue were flooded during heavy rain.

Sennett Estate is served by the MacPherson Road Outlet Drain. PUB has completed works in September 2011 to widen and deepen this stormwater drain. As a result, rainwater can be better channelled out of the estate in the event of heavy rain, thus reducing the flood risk within Sennett Estate. In addition, there are also ongoing drainage improvement works on roadside drains at Jalan Kemboja, Mulberry Avenue, Jalan Wangi and back lane drains around Siang Kuang Avenue to further improve overall drainage for the area. The works are expected to be completed by the end of 2012. PUB has worked with residents to gather feedback to enhance the localised drainage within the estate. Some of the suggestions to improve the drainage flow were subsequently integrated into current drainage improvement works.

Notwithstanding these efforts, the low-lying nature of the estate means flooding may continue to occur in the event of unusually heavy rain. The long-term solution to achieve a higher level of flood protection in the estate would be to raise the ground and road levels in conjunction with future redevelopment plans. Units in the estate that were recently re-developed have also adopted higher platform levels to improve the flood protection for these units.

In the meantime, to prevent floodwaters from entering residents' homes, PUB has installed flood boards and supplied sand bags for affected residents. The drains in the estate are also regularly cleansed and inspected to ensure that the drainage system remains clear of debris and is in good working condition.

PUB has arranged for liaison officers whom the residents could contact for assistance. Residents can subscribe to SMS alerts for heavy rain and water level information via PUB's website (www.pub.gov.sg/managingflashfloods) for advance warning on the water levels during heavy rain. Ahead of the upcoming Northeast Monsoon season, PUB has also disseminated flood warning advisories to at-risk residents in Siang Kuang and Puay Hee Avenue.

Evidence from NEA Meteorological Services Singapore (MSS) has shown that the maximum rainfall intensities in Singapore have increased in the last 30 years. Apart from enhancing the drainage design standards to cater for more intense rainfall, PUB will also enhance its modelling and predictive capabilities to enable the drainage system to be adaptive for potential changes in rainfall intensities. I would like to assure Mr Sitoh that PUB takes a serious view of floods, and PUB will continuously work with stakeholders in flood prone areas and flooding hotspots to protect residents and properties from flooding.
