Palestine's Membership in UNESCO

26 Mr Pritam Singh asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs what are the reasons behind Singapore's decision to abstain from voting to grant Palestine full membership in the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

Mr K Shanmugam : Singapore has long supported the establishment of a Palestinian state as part of a negotiated two-state solution, which will see Israel and Palestine living side by side in peace and security. But in our judgement, the recent move to grant Palestine full membership in UNESCO would not contribute to such a solution.

Singapore was one of the 52 countries that had abstained on the vote to admit Palestine into UNESCO. We understand and sympathise with the desire of the Palestinians to become a member of UNESCO. But the application could not be considered apart from its broader political context. More importantly, it is also questionable whether it would help or hinder UNESCO's primary mission of promoting education, science and culture.

From the reactions to the application and the outcome of the vote, it is evident that UNESCO had been seriously divided and possibly weakened by this issue. The politically fraught atmosphere hinders UNESCO's primary mission – Members would have read in the media that the US Congress has cut funding to UNESCO which was entirely predictable. That dimension has been ignored by those who sought Palestinian membership. It also adds a further complication to the already complicated negotiations over the Palestinian issue and has set back those negotiations.

Furthermore, the application was submitted just after Palestine had applied to the UN Security Council for full membership in the UN. That application is still under the Council's consideration in New York. Therefore, we could not ignore the fact that UNESCO's decision would have a political impact. It is not part of UNESCO's mandate to play such a political role. As such, we decided to abstain from voting on the UNESCO's application.

Noise Levels from Highways Located Near Residential Areas

30 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is being done to minimise the noise transmitted from highways that are built in close proximity to residential areas; (b) how are noise levels measured, sampled and monitored; and (c) in affected areas, how do the measured noise levels compare with international benchmarks for noise pollution.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : There are several levels of measures to minimise road noise and its impact.

Page: 650

At the land use planning stage, the Land Transport Authority (LTA), together with the National Environment Agency (NEA) and the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), incorporates noise mitigation measures in public housing developments. As far as possible, non-noise sensitive developments such as industries, recreational facilities and parks are located next to expressways and arterial roads to act as noise shields. Developers of residential dwellings must also adhere to URA's building setback requirements to ensure a minimum distance between the facade of buildings and roads.

In addition, LTA uses a special type of road pavement (Open Graded Wearing Course) on expressways to reduce road noise. Greenery is also planted along the sides of expressways and arterial roads to act as visual screens and reduce the transmission of road noise.

NEA regulates noise emission levels from road vehicles. New vehicles, including motorcycles, are required to meet noise emission standards before they are registered for use. In-use vehicles are required to pass noise emission tests during their mandatory periodic inspections for road tax renewal. NEA regularly updates the noise emission standards to keep pace with the advancement in vehicle noise control technology. LTA and the Traffic Police also conduct enforcement blitzes against noisy vehicles on the road.

Measurements of road noise are taken at the facade of residential buildings fronting the road for a period of 1 hour during peak hours. This provides the Equivalent Noise Level for an hour [Leq(1hr)], which is the standard unit used internationally.

NEA's guideline is 67dBA Leq(1hr). Countries such as Hong Kong and Japan have similar noise guidelines ranging from 60 to 70dBA Leq(1hr) depending on the time of the day. In a highly urbanised city like Singapore, we are mindful that our roads may sometimes have to be near residential units. NEA and LTA have thus embarked on a joint study, involving URA, the Housing and Development Board (HDB) and the National Parks Board, to look into the noise levels near expressways, major arterial roads and elevated rail lines, and explore appropriate noise mitigating measures that are applicable to our local context. The study is expected to be completed by the first half of 2012.

In addition, SBST started operating Punggol East LRT in two directions throughout the day instead of only during the morning peak. Table 1 - Accidents Involving SBS Transit Buses

Table 2 - Accidents Involving SMRT Buses

Under the Public Transport Council (PTC)'s Quality of Service (QoS) standards, bus operators are required to keep the number of accidents per 100,000 bus-km under 0.75 per month, to ensure commuter safety. All accidents are included in the computation of this accident rate, regardless of whether the driver was at fault or not. These also include accidents that do not involve other vehicles, such as when passengers are injured by closing doors, or when they fall while alighting. Failure to meet the standard attracts a financial penalty of $10,000 per month. SBST and SMRT Buses have not been penalised for failing this requirement since the introduction of the QoS standards in 2006.

Places for Programmes in Publicly-Funded Universities

36 Ms Ellen Lee asked the Minister for Education (a) what are the principles and guidelines in calibrating the number of places for each programme in our three publicly-funded universities and whether these are changed each year prior to an intake; (b) whether there is a quota for each of these programmes and, if so, whether the quotas are usually filled up; and (c) whether there will be a review of these principles and guidelines and, if so, why and when will the review be published.

Mr Heng Swee Keat : Each year, MOE works closely with the Ministry of Manpower, the Ministry of Trade and Industry, and other economic agencies under the aegis of the National Manpower Council (NMC) to plan the total number and distribution of publicly-funded degree places across broad discipline clusters.

The NMC takes into account the overall manpower needs by different industry sectors and student preferences. This process ensures good employment prospects for the students upon graduation, and offers opportunities that meet the different interests and abilities of our students.

Based on the broad parameters set by the Ministries, universities decide on their programme offerings and intake targets, after taking into consideration the number of faculty, the availability of facilities, and the optimal class size to run a programme without compromising the quality of the student's educational experience. The universities have generally been able to meet their intake targets.

MOE periodically undertakes reviews to determine the overall provision of publicly-funded university places and the appropriate balance of places across various disciplines. Most recently, the Committee on University Education Pathways chaired by Minister of State (Defence and Education) Mr Lawrence Wong was established to examine how the university sector could better provide opportunities for more Singaporeans to benefit from a university education. The Committee expects to finalise and submit its recommendations to the Government by end-2012.

Promoting Teaching Excellence in Institutes of Higher Education

38 Ms Ellen Lee asked the Minister for Education in view of the recently published "The Higher Education World University Rankings 2011-12" where NUS and NTU are ranked 41st and 123rd in the teaching component (a) whether the Ministry will consider forming a Council for Teaching Excellence in Higher Education to promote and ensure teaching excellence in institutes of higher education; and (b) whether NUS and NTU aim to perform better.

Mr Heng Swee Keat : Our Autonomous Universities (AUs) are committed to providing high quality education for their students. Course curriculum are regularly reviewed for industry relevance and updated with relevant new knowledge. In hiring faculty members, the AUs also rigorously assess their ability on both teaching and research. As part of their efforts to continually improve the quality of their teaching, NUS and NTU have their own Centres for Teaching and Learning that conduct training programmes in pedagogy for their faculty members, and hold international conferences to share effective teaching and learning practices.

The Ministry of Education (MOE) also conducts quality assurance validation reviews to assess the performance of the AUs. These reviews cover areas including Teaching and Learning and are carried out by panels commissioned by MOE, comprising experienced and eminent local industry captains and international academics. Apart from studying the relevant data and papers, they also conduct interviews with faculty, students and other stakeholders.

International rankings are useful in providing a high-level comparison among disparate institutions in different countries, but are subject to regular methodological revisions and challenges in obtaining quality inputs in all areas. This is particularly so in the area of teaching, where assessments and comparisons are hard to do.

Nonetheless, there is always room to do better to raise the quality of teaching. Our universities will continue to seek improvements in this area, to create a more conducive learning experience for our students.

Education Subsidies for Permanent Residents

39 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Education what is the total amount of Government subsidy given to a Permanent Resident student who completes his/her primary to tertiary education in our public education system.

Page: 656

Mr Heng Swee Keat : The priority of our education system is to provide a quality education for students who are Singapore Citizens (SC). However, Permanent Residents (PR) who enrol in our education system add diversity to the student population and provide our children exposure to different cultures from a young age. More importantly, we should welcome PR children in our education system, so that they are well integrated into our society.

Across our publicly-funded education system, from primary school to university, the Government provides the highest subsidies for SC, followed by PR and International Students (IS). Accordingly, IS pays the highest fees, followed by PR, then SC, to reflect the privileges of citizenship.

For school fees, which were increased sharply for non-citizens recently, PR in primary and secondary schools pay annual fees of around $600 to $850, which works out to a cost recovery ratio (CRR) of 9%. In comparison, citizens pay annual fees of around $130 and $250, at a CRR of 2%. For tertiary education, the CRR for citizens is set at 25% and 15% for university and polytechnic respectively. PR who receive tuition grant also pay subsidised fees, but with CRR set at higher rates of around 30% for university and 25% for polytechnic. At the same time, they need to sign a bond to work in Singapore for three years.

The Government also provides further help to students who are SC through financial assistance schemes, such as Edusave Accounts and the MOE and CDC/CCC bursary schemes. These schemes are not open to PR.
